loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Chan N. is is 29 years old and from Run village in Takeo province. He is a motorbike taxi driver, and his wife, Mrs. Oun Phem, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows crops. The couple has four children between six and sixteen years of age, and they are all students in the local school.

Chan is the village’s president of a loan group consisting of fifteen members. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. In his case, Chan is requesting 800,000 KHR from AMK to buy lumber to repair his home.

loans.use: To buy lumber to repair his house.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen S., age 35, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has four children, two of whom study at a local primary school.

S. is engaged in growing vegetables such as morning glories and garlic, earning approximately $3 in revenue per day. She has been in this business since 1993. Her husband is a police officer in the province, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses.

Their standard of living has been improved since they have these businesses, so they want to have a loan to expand their businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase a car for her husband to provide transportation services. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a car for her husband to provide transportation services

loans.name: Mareta

texts.en:
Mareta E. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 31 years old. Mareta is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mareta owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily-use products in the local community. Mareta has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mareta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mareta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mareta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mareta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en: This group loan, which consists of 5 people located in Trapeang Tuem village, Takeo province, is led by Mrs. Phally L.. The loan will be used to purchase supplies, equipment, and other items for different purposes. Mrs. Phally L. is a farmer, and her husband, Mr. Sararn Prum is a laborer. In addition to being a farmer, Mrs. Phally L. is a food and drinks seller who earns a small income to support her family. In order to support her business, she is now requesting a loan to purchase more drinks and more supplies for her food sales. She hopes to be successful and increase her income with this loan. Mrs. Phally L. is 42 years old, and she is a mother of two children who are attending the local school.

loans.name: Ma. Luzelle

texts.en:
Ma. Luzelle O. is from the village of Northern Poblacion, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Luzelle owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of foods in the local community. Ma. Luzelle has been engaged in her business for 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ma. Luzelle joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Luzelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ma. Luzelle from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Mariel

texts.en:
To get married to the father of her two children (four and three years old) and her partner, Roel, is the wish of 22-year-old Mariel C.. Just like other women, she dreams of wearing a gown and marching down the aisle of the church with their two children walking ahead of them, bearing their wedding ring and veil. However, because of the small and sporadic income generated by her husband, who is a laborer, it will take time for Mariel’s dream wedding to happen. Thinking about it always in addition to her dream of sending her children to school and supporting them until they graduate from college pushes Mariel to come up with other options for earning money in her own way. Therefore, she thought of selling food in a bus terminal, since people traveling and passing through their town wait long hours before taking off in the vehicle. Most often, they are very hungry for meals upon being dropped off at the station. With that, she is requesting a loan which she will use to purchase ingredients, utensils, and the rented space she will occupy.

With Mariel’s planned business, she hopes to sustain it until it grows big. Its proceeds would bring her to her dreams for herself and her family.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients, utensils, and the rental space to start her food selling business

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
54-year-old Marjorie D.’s dream in life is to support her three children, despite the fact that her two eldest children already have families of their own. She wants to be a good grandmother to her grandchildren and be someone they can run to when their parents do not have enough money for their needs. With that, Marjorie wants to grow her small “sari-sari” (variety) store using the loan she is requesting through ASHI.

“Sari-sari” is a Filipino term for variety, and “sari-sari” stores are variety stores that sell items to meet the basic needs of people in the village everyday. This offers convenience, especially to those who live far away from the main town, just like in Marjorie’s village. Marjorie wishes for her store to someday grow into a grocery store, which sells more inventory and can make more profits to meet her family's needs.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of a "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Matlуuba

texts.ru: Сафарова Матлюба проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 22 года. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Муж работает в городе Душанбе. Сама Матлюба занимается торговлей. Она более 5 лет занимается приготовлением пирожков и их продажей на рынке. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Matlуuba S. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 22 years old, married, and has one child. Her husband works in the city of Dushanbe, while Matlyuba herself makes pies and sells them on the market. She has been in this business for over five years and is seeking a loan in order to increase the sales volume.

Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sales volume increase

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos G. is from the village of Bunawan in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. He is 43 years old and married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Carlos plants, harvests and sells vegetables in the local community. Carlos has been engaged in his business for 2 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Carlos joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlos is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to finance his vegetable gardening. This will be Carlos's first loan from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for his business

loans.name: Nora Gladys

texts.es: Nora Gladys R. D. R. D. 45 años D. edad, resiD. en el municipio D. Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador. Vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como agente D. la Policía Nacional Civil, y junto a sus tres hijas D. 18, 10 y 2 años D. edad, D. las cuales la mayor se dedica a trabajar en un almacén y la segunda a estudiar educación básica. Nora se dedica a la venta D. perfumes y ropa para hombres y mujeres, la cual la comercializa en su hogar y así mismo D. manera ambulante por las colonias D. Soyapango y en el Ministerio D. Salud, lugar en el cual es muy conocida por su amabilidad y calidad en sus productos. Nora solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar más perfumería y mayor cantidad D. ropa en diferentes tallas y estilos. El mayor deseo D. Nora es poder aumentar sus ventas y D. esta manera brindarle más ayuda a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, ya que los ingresos obtenidos por el  trabajo D. su compañero D. vida no dan abasto para todas las necesidades del hogar, es por ello que Nora se esfuerza con el deseo D. poder obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Nora Gladys R. D. R. is 45 years old, lives in the Soyapango municipality located in San Salvador. She lives with her husband, who works as an agent of the National Civil Police, and with her three daughters ages 18, 10 and two. The oldest daughter works in a warehouse and the 10 year old is in elementary school. Nora sells perfumes and clothing for men and women from home. She also sells in the neighborhoods of Soyapango and Ministry of Health, areas where is known for her good service and product quality. Nora requests a loan to be able to purchase perfumes and clothing of different sizes and styles. Nora's biggest wish is to be able to increase sales and help her husband with the home expenses, because the current income obtained by her partner in life is not sufficient for the family needs; this is why Nora works hard with the wish to have more income.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing and perfumes.

loans.name: Noemí Del Carmen

texts.es: Noemí del Carmen G. D. R. D. 56 años D. edad, resiD. en Soyapango, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador. Vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como vigilante D. una empresa privada y junto a sus dos hijos D. 17 y  10 años D. edad. Noemí se dedica a vender ropa, por las mañanas la comercializa en la calle principal D. Soyapango, una D. las calles más concurridas del lugar debido a que existen varios supermercados y comerciales en el lugar. Así mismo por las tardes Noemí venD. la ropa D. forma ambulante, ofreciéndola por las calles y pasajes D. las colonias D. este municipio. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. ropa, en diferentes tallas y colores, esto lo hace con el deseo D. poder obtener mayor cantidad D. clientes y así percibir más ganancias, lo cual es muy importante para Noemí ya que el sueldo D. su esposo es bastante bajo para solventar todos los gastos del hogar, razón por la cual Noemí se esfuerza mucho por mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Noemí del Carmen G. D. R. is 56 years old and a resident of Soyapango, which is located in the Department of San Salvador. She lives with her husband, who works as a security guard at a private company, and their two children, ages 17 and 10. Noemí sells clothing in the mornings along the main street of Soyapango, which is one of the busiest places because of the different supermarkets and businesses found at this location. In the afternoons she sells clothing as a traveling merchant, offering her products as she passes through different neighborhoods.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy a larger quantity of clothes in different sizes and colors. Noemí hopes this will help her attract more customers and generate better earnings. This is very important because her husband’s salary is not enough to cover all of their household expenses. For this reason, she works extremely hard to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing in larger quantities

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es: Pedro P. V. de 44 años de edad, vive junto a su esposa quien se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar, y junto a sus dos hijas de 14 y 4 años de edad, las cuales se dedican a estudiar. Pedro reside en Sacacoyo, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad, lugar en el cual él posee su propio negocio, el cual es una venta de productos comestibles y de primera necesidad para el hogar. Desde hace alguno años atrás, Pedro decidió emprender su propio negocio, esto debido a la necesidad de contar con una fuente de ingresos, ya que él no contaba con un trabajo, y debido a la difícil situación a la que se enfrentaba, decidió no quedarse con los brazos cruzado e inició comprando algunos productos de primera necesidad para comercializar en su hogar, de esta manera poco a poco fue surtiendo su negocio. A  pesar de que cuenta con clientela fija, Pedro no ha podido suministrar la tienda con todo lo que sus clientes le piden. Es por esta razón que el solicita un préstamo, con el fin de poder aumentar su inventario comprando productos como leche, embutidos, pan y otros más, los cuales incrementarían sus ventas, permitiéndole a Pedro, brindarle una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Pedro P. V. is 44 years old. He lives with his wife, who works around the house, and with his 2 daughters, 14 and 4 years of age, who both study. Pedro resides in Sacacoyo, located in La Libertad department, a place where he has his own business selling grocery products and necessary household items. Several years ago Pedro decided to start his own business, owing to the neeed to have a stream of revenue, since he didn't have a job. In the face of this difficult situation he decided not to cross his arms and do nothing and began buying some grocery items to sell at his home. In this way, little by little, he began stocking his business. Although Pedro has steady customers he hasn't been able to supply the shop with all that his customers ask of him. It is for this reason that he is seeking a loan, with the aim of being able to increase his inventory, purchasing products such as milk, cold meats, bread and other things, which will increase his sales and allow Pedro to give a better life to his family.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grocery products

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta K. is from the village of Dicayas. She is 50 years old. Modesta is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Modesta is a tailor. She does tailoring and alterations for local community members. Modesta has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Modesta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Modesta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Modesta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional fabric and materials. This will be Modesta's 11th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabric and materials

loans.name: Dina Esther

texts.es: Dina Esther V. R. de 30 años de edad, reside en Lourdes colón, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto a su compañero de vida y su único hijo de dos años de edad. Ella posee una venta de ropa para hombres, mujeres y niños, la cual esta ubicada en el Mercado Municipal d Lourdes Colón, lugar en el cual durante más de 5 años ha tratado de seguir adelante con su negocio, ya que es este el que le permite solventar todos los gastos del hogar junto a su esposo. Dina solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa, sobre todo ropa para jóvenes la cual esta muy de moda, lo que le permita ser más fácil de vender. Esto es vital para Dina ya que la estabilidad de su hogar depende en gran manera de las ganancias obtenidas por ella. Para Dina el bienestar de su familia es primero, razón por la cual cada día de 8 de la mañana a 6 de la tarde ofrece su producto a las personas que visitan el mercado, esto con la esperanza de poder obtener mejores ventas.
texts.en:
Dina Esther V. R. is 30 years old and a resident of Lourdes Colón, which is located in the Department of La Libertad. She lives with her lifelong partner and their only child who is two years old. Dina sells clothing for men, women, and children at the municipal market in Lourdes Colón. She started this business more than five years ago because she wanted to join her husband in meeting the household expenses.

Dina is requesting a loan so that she can buy clothing in larger quantities, particularly the trendier clothes for young people because they are easier to sell. Her business is vital since the stability of her household depends largely on the income that she is able to earn. Dina says her family’s wellbeing is her highest priority. For this reason, she works each day from 8am until 6pm and offers her products to people who visit the market. She hopes to generate better sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes in different colors & sizes

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Cendana Indah (Group A)

texts.en:
The Cendana Indah Group A comprises 15 women from the Kaliakah Village near the town of Melaya in northwest Bali. These women manage various businesses ranging from shop traders, to cattle and pig farmers, to produce sellers. 

The group, which is led by a chairwoman and treasurer (pictured above) requested a loan of Rp. 10,000,000 which will be distributed to group members according to their individual needs and business skills. The chairwoman of the group is responsible for the borrowing of all the members and for assuring that the money is shared equally in accordance with their business needs. At the end of the loan period, the chairwoman and treasurer will collect the repayments from each member in a group meeting.

One member of this group is Ni Luh B.. Ni Luh B. owns a shop where she sells chicken soup, beef meatballs, and various kinds of cakes and soft drinks. Her portion of the loan is approximately Rp. 500,000. She will use her loan to buy a glass shelf and stall equipment to make her restaurant kiosk look more attractive. Her daily revenue from her business ranges from Rp. 30,000-50,000. Profits from her store go to pay for school fees for her two children, who are currently in elementary and junior high school.

Note to Kiva Lenders: This group uses a community lending model commonly referred to as "village banking" that is very common throughout Asia. In this model, a select number of group representatives borrow a large loan on behalf of their entire group, often an entire village. They will then distribute and manage the loan and collect repayments for the lender. This is a common and efficient practice in the region, but it makes reporting on Kiva somewhat unusual. Unlike most other loans, Kiva’s partner MUK will be in contact primarily with the group leadership team, who in turn will be overseeing the end borrowers. As such, journal updates likely will reflect the performance of the lending group rather than the individual borrowers.   
 
To learn more about village banking, see this Wikipedia article: Village Banking.

loans.use: To buy a glass shelf and stall equipment for her restaurant

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda J. faced the challenge of being a single parent to her only three-year-old son, RJ, for several years after being separated from her husband. Now she lives with her new-found partner and, with him, she hopes to face tomorrow’s adversities and give her child a better kind of life. 

Restarting life with her partner, Florinda wants to have a business that will provide them income. Since their town is famous and well-known for handicrafts, she wanted to have financial capital through a loan to start marketing these products to other regions and to the neighboring provinces, including tourist spots, such as Boracay, province of Aklan. 

Transporting products from the Island of Panay (where Antique province is located) is now easier than in the past years before they discovered “RORO" ("roll-on/roll-off"), which are ships (barges and ferries) that carry cars, trucks and buses, as well as passengers.

“RORO” started its operation fours years ago. People of low and middle economic status, businessman, and other tourists take this transportation for adventure and its cheaper fares. It is convenient for transporting products because a person can bring their car with them. Just like passenger buses, cars roll on the barge to cross the ocean and then roll off the barge and travel by land to their destination. The situation is repeated until each one reaches Manila as their final destination.

loans.use: To purchase mats and other handicrafts to sell

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni E. sells tea and bread in a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of sugar to sell. Poni is 30 years old and is married to a clerk. She has 4 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of sugar to sell.

loans.name: Rosa Del Carmen

texts.es: Rosa del Carmen T. J. de 30 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Ahuachapán. Vive junto a su esposo el cual se dedica a trabajar en construcción, así mismo vive junto a sus dos hijos menores de edad los cuales estudian educación básica en la escuela del lugar. Rosa posee una venta de tortillas desde hace un par de años atrás, debido a la necesidad que su familia, Rosa tomó la decisión de convertirse en la ayuda económica de su esposo, lo cual le permitió solventar junto a su esposo todos los gastos del hogar. Ella trabaja haciendo y vendiendo las tortillas en el mediodía y en las noches, contado con la ventaja de ser la única tortillería en los alrededores de su hogar, gracias a esto Rosa cuenta con un negocio muy estable el cual le permite obtener ganancias muy buenas. Es por esto que ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar maíz por mayor, para de esta manera atender mayor cantidad de clientes y así obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Rosa del Carmen T. J. is 30 years old and a resident of the Department of Ahuachapán. She lives with her husband, who is a construction worker, and their two dependent children who are studying in a basic education program at the local school. Rosa started selling tortillas two years out of family necessity. She decided that she should help her husband with covering their household expenses.

Rosa makes and sells tortillas at noon and in the evenings. She has the advantage of being the only tortilla stand in her neighborhood. Rosa has been able to build a very stable business that generates good revenues. For this reason, she is requesting a loan so that she can buy corn in bulk so that she can serve more customers and generate a better income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn in bulk

loans.name: María Del Transito

texts.es: María del Transito C. D. R. D. 51 años D. edad, resiD. en Atiquizaya, ubicado en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Su grupo familiar esta conformado por su esposo y cuatro hijos los cuales se dedican a estudiar, y que son el mayor incentivo tanto para María como para su esposo. Ella se destaca por ser una madre D. familia muy responsable en todo lo que realiza, así mismo es muy amable y trabajadora. María posee un molino, en el cual muele frijoles, maíz, café y otros productos más. El negocio esta ubicado en su propia casa D. habitación, lugar en el cual muchas veces sus hijos le ayudan a atender el negocio, ya que María cuenta con muchos clientes, los cuales llegan a moler a diario el maíz para sus negocios D. tortillas y otro tipo D. alimentos. María solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar algunos repuestos para el molino y D. esta manera mantenerlo siempre en buen estado, así mismo desea poder extender su negocio vendiendo granos básicos, esto con el fin D. obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
María del Transito C. D. R., 51, lives in Atiquizaya, Ahuachapán department. Her family is composed of her husband and four children, who are students and who are María and her husband’s greatest incentive in life. María is known for being a very responsible mother in everything she does; she is also very kind and hard-working. She has a mill where she grinds beans, corn, coffee and other products, too. The business is located in her home and her children help her out often because María has a lot of customers who come daily to grind corn for their tortilla and other food businesses. She is requesting funding to buy some replacement parts for the mill so that she can always have it in good working order. She also wants to expand her business and start selling basic grains in order to obtain higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains and mill replacement parts.

loans.name: Redi Gul Group

texts.en:
This is Redi G. group which has three members: Redi G., Abdul Ghafoor and Javeed.

Redi G., who is the group leader, is married with four children: two sons and two daughters. He runs a general store. Currently his business income is not satisfactory to meet his family needs and also he has lots of economic problems. He wants to take a loan to meet his family needs and solve his economic problems.

The second member is Javeed who sells vegetables. Currently, his business income is not enough to match his family needs. He wants to take a loan to purchase different kinds of vegetables to progress his business income, expand his business capacity and complete his family needs.

The last member is Abdul Ghafor who is a taxi driver. He wants to take a loan to buy new seat material and repair his taxi’s engine.

Therefore, together they have requested a group loan of 25,000 Afghani. They are thankful for Kiva and all the Kiva lenders who support them. Your timely assistance allows them to develop their businesses.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for his general store

loans.name: Cendana Indah (Group B)

texts.en:
Cendana Indah Group B is comprised of fifteen women from Kaliakah village near the town of Melaya in northwest Bali. These women manage various types of businesses ranging from shop traders, to cattle and pig farmers, to produce sellers. The group, which is led by a chairwoman and treasurer (pictured above) requested a loan of Rp. 9,999,990 which will be distributed to the group members according to their individual needs and business skills.

The chairwoman of the group is responsible for the borrowing of all the members and to share the money equally in accordance with their business needs. At the end of the loan period, the chairwoman and treasurer will collect the repayments from each member in a group meeting.

One of the members of the group is Ni Komang Karleni who has a business in the school cafeteria. Her portion of this loan is Rp. 350,000 which will be used to buy foods that are sold such as rice packets, fried noodles, chicken soup, porridge, various snack foods and soft drinks. Each day she begins selling at 6 a.m. Her clients are mostly school children, but also people from the area. Her efforts are in demand because her food is very good and cheap.

Ni Komang Karleni’s income per day is approximately Rp. 60,000. Her income goes towards capital for her shop, everyday needs, and personal savings. She was only educated through junior high school level so she wants her son to be able to attend school up to university level so he can improve his life.


Note to Kiva Lenders:  
This group uses a community lending model (commonly referred to as Village Banking) that is very common throughout Asia. In this model, a select number of group representatives will take out a large loan on behalf of their entire group (often an entire village). They will then distribute and manage the loan and collect repayments for the lender.

This is a common and efficient practice in the region, but it makes reporting on Kiva somewhat unusual. Unlike most other loans, Kiva’s partner, MUK, will be in contact primarily with the group leadership team who in turn will be overseeing the end borrowers. As such, journal updates likely will reflect the performance of the lending group rather than the individual end borrowers.
 
To learn more about Village Banking on Wikipedia, please click here.

loans.use: To buy foods that are sold in her business

loans.name: Ponchita

texts.en:
Ponchita U. is a 51-year-old mother who always dreamed of happiness for her family. She has three children whose ages are from seven to twenty-five years old.

Even though Ponchita feels sad for her two eldest children who were in college but didn’t want to continue their education and are jobless at the present time, her love for them prevails and she realizes that she has to respect their decisions. Therefore, she decided to support them especially in their financial needs.

Just recently, Ponchita joined ASHI and now she is requesting a loan which she is going to use for starting up her own small business which is hog/pig fattening. Her loan will be used to buy a piglet and enough feed for four months. When is it mature and sold, she plans to buy another one by requesting another loan.

The proceeds will be used to support Ponchita’s children in addition to the allowance sent to her by her husband who works abroad as an Overseas Contract Worker.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and a piglet to raise and sell

loans.name: Fishmonger B Oringa Hellen Group

texts.en:
O. Hellen is a married businesswoman, forty-seven years old. She is blessed with seven children, all going to school. She also has four dependents schooling and, more so, she is looking after her mother.

Hellen operates a fish-selling business which she has been doing for over twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase fish which she is selling to Sudan. The loan is helping her raise her capital and, more so, she is encouraged to work very hard to meet her targets.

Hellen’s future hope is to educate her children through school.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Saydali

texts.ru: Камолов Сайдали проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 32 года. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Сайдали более 4 лет занимаеся животноводством. Он откармливает и продает крупно- рогатый скот. В этой деятельности ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота. Сайдали хочет купить молодого бычка и продать по высокой цене.
texts.en:
Saydali K. lives in the Yavan district. He is 32 years old, married and has 3 children. Saydali has been involved in animal husbandry for over 4 years. He raises and sells cattle. His wife helps him with this business. Saydali is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle. He wants to buy a young bull and resell it at a higher price.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gerlie

texts.en:
Gerlie is a 24-year-old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has a one-year-old child who inspires her to work hard to improve her family’s living conditions.

Gerlie started farming when she was still single. She learned it from her parents. Now that she has her own family, she and her husband work together to keep their rice farm productive.

Gerlie is a new member of CEVI. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 which she will use to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies she needs. Receiving this loan is truly helpful to Gerlie’s farming.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
45-year-old Ricardo farms for a living. He is from Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. He is married and has two children and his oldest child is now 22 years old.

Ricardo cultivates his land for rice crops. The farm is the only source of income his family has so he makes sure it is productive.

Ricardo recently joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain its financial services. He applied for a loan of Php 6,000, which he will use to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer.

Ricardo is hopeful that this loan will help double his harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn P. is a 40-year-old hardworking mother who dreams of having a denture. Anyhow, she feels so insecure about her looks especially when she deals with her customers. That is why, with the loan she is requesting for the first time through ASHI, she will try her best to grow her fish selling business to be able to have more profit so that she can afford a denture.

Aside from that, Analyn also wishes to invest in raising farm animals someday to supplement the proceeds of her fish-selling business and to have the capability to send four of her children, aged from 7 to 14 years old, to college. Her two eldest children, who are from 18 to 20 years old, chose not to continue their education and help her earn money instead.

Fernando, Analyn’s husband, is a fisherman and a source of Analyn’s fish for selling, in addition to the volume she buys from other fisher folk in their village.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Hugo Alexander

texts.es: Hugo Alexander G. G. de 31 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Cojutepeque. Vive únicamente junto a su madre la cual se encarga de los quehaceres del hogar. Hugo posee una venta de medicina natural, de una marca muy reconocida, la cual comercializa de manera ambulante por los diferentes lugares de Cojutepeque, así mismo vende su producto en el pueblo de Sensuntepeque, siempre dentro del mismo departamento de Cuscatlán. Hugo es una persona muy emprendedora, quien se esfuerza mucho por lograr mejores ventas cada día, ya que debe solventar todos los gastos del hogar. Él solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de medicina, ya que esta la compra al contado, pero a diferencia de esto Hugo vende su producto a crédito, razón por la cual el necesita contar con el dinero para comprar las medicinas. Desde hace 3 años que él se dedica a este tipo de trabajo, contando con la fortuna de poseer muchos clientes los cuales consumen mucho de su producto, lo que es de mucho beneficio para Hugo.
texts.en:
Hugo Alexander G. G., 31, lives in Cojutepeque with his mother, who takes care of household chores. Hugo travels to the various neighborhoods of Cojutepeque selling a very well-known brand of naturalistic medicinal products. He also sells his products in the town of Sensuntepeque, also in Cuscatlán department. Hugo is a very enterprising person, who makes every effort to attain good sales daily because he is responsible for all household expenses. He is asking for funding to buy a larger quantity of medicines, since he must pay cash, but, because he sells on credit, has to have capital available to buy his stock. He has been in this line of work for three years and he is fortunate to have a large base of regular customers who are good consumers of his product line; this is of great benefit for Hugo.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy naturalistic medicines.

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Mamya

texts.en: Mamya S. is currently in the business of selling tea at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase tables and chairs. Mamya is 28 years old and is divorced. She has four children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase tables and chairs for her restaurant

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet P. is from the village of Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old, is married and has four school-aged children. Juliet owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Cathy

texts.en:
Cathy T. is a 30-year-old single mother who wants to have someone to spend her life with and to share the responsibility of raising her only two-year-old child. For now, she wants to be a good mother by providing her child things that would make him happy despite their poverty. With that, Cathy is requesting a loan through ASHI, which will enable her to start up a hog/pig fattening business.  

Fattening hogs is very convenient for her and her two-year-old son. While she stays at home and looks after her son, she can look after her hog and feed it until it is ready to sell in four months time. Her proceeds will be used for her child’s needs and the capital will be re-invested in the same business in addition to the loan she will be applying for again the next time. Someday she hopes to fatten more hogs to increase her profit and improve her life and her son's life.

loans.use: To purchase a pig

loans.name: Elsie Ratiza Group

texts.en:
Elsie R. is from the village of Bato, Plaridel. She is 43 years old. Elsie is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elsie R..

Elsie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Elsie owns & operates a business planting & harvesting rice for sale. Elsie has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elsie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Elsie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Brenda Carolina

texts.es: Brenda Carolina R. V. de 24 años de edad, reside en Lourdes Colón, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto su abuela y su pequeño hijo de 2 años de edad. Brenda posee una venta de ropa para niños, mujeres y hombres, la cual esta ubicada en el centro de Lourdes, uno de los lugares con más afluencia del lugar. A su edad, Brenda es una joven quien debe trabajar y esforzar mucho por lograr obtener ganancias, las cuales le permitan solventar todos los gastos de la familia, sobre todo porque es ella la única que trabaja por el sustento de su hogar. Es por esta razón que Brenda solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa, de manera que pueda obtener nuevos clientes y mantener satisfechos a los que ya posee. Esto es de mucha importancia para Brenda, es por ello que cada día se dispone a vender la ropa, gritando en las calles a las personas, invitándolas de esta manera a que vean su producto y se decidan a comprarlo.
texts.en:
Brenda Carolina R. V., 24, lives in Lourdes Colón, La Libertad department with her grandmother and two-year-old son. Brenda has a small men’s, women’s and children’s clothing sales business located in downtown Lourdes, one of the busiest parts of town. At her young age, Brenda must work hard to earn enough to meet household expenses especially because she is the only source of income for the family. For this reason, Brenda is asking for funding to buy a large amount of clothing so that she can both attract new customers and keep her current customers satisfied. This is very important for Brenda and why she goes out into the streets every day to call out to potential customers inviting them to examine her wares and choose to buy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing at wholesale.

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Edlyn

texts.en: To work abroad is one of the dreams of 28-year-old Edlyn C.. After her separation from her husband, she became the sole provider and support for  her four-year-old daughter Stephanie. Because of her bitter experiences in life brought about by poverty, Edlyn wishes that someday she would have enough money to change her life and to make her daughter’s childhood days memorable and enjoyable. Moreover, Edlyn wants her daughter to finish her education through college. Therefore, she wants to have a business to have a source of money to support her dreams. Edlyn, being a newly recognized member of ASHI, is requesting a loan to start up a small business. She plans to raise chickens in her backyard and sell them after 40 days. Some of the eggs her chickens will produce will be for their own consumption, some will be sold, and some will be hatched to be raised again. If Edlyn feels happy and successful running a business, she would prefer not to go abroad and would look after her daughter instead.

loans.use: To purchase chicks

loans.name: Pascuala

texts.en:
Mrs. Pascuala T. has been married to her husband, Manuel, for 46 years now. She is 64 years old and has six children, most of whom have their own families already.

At her age, Pascuala still works on her rice farm because she wants to support her family financially. She does not mind spending most of her time on the farm. She also joined CEVI upon hearing good feedback from her fellow farmers. She thinks its program is really helpful to farmers like her who are in need of additional capital.

Pascuala is requesting to loan of Php 6,000. She told CEVI that this loan would be spent on farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina tills a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field. She is 48 years old, married and has two children.

The farm is the only source of income Avelina’s family has. She and her husband spend their whole day at the farm. She helps her husband keep the farm free of weeds and pests. They both want it to be productive and are hoping that the harvest will be plenty.

Avelina applied to CEVI and asked to loan Php 6,000 to fund their farm. She will be able to purchase farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer with this amount.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en: Hilda P. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Hilda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Hilda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Hilda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will again be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida is a 40-year-old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has two children and her oldest child is only 17 years old. Adelaida works hard to be able to support her family financially. She also wants to sustain her children’s education.

Adelaida started farming in 2000 and plants rice crops on her farm. She is now preparing her land for planting and she hopes to have an abundant harvest. She applied for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI which, she said, would truly help her achieve her goal to have an abundant harvest. She will use the loan to acquire farm supplies like the fertilizer that she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like fertilizer

loans.name: Rehema Samuel

texts.en:
Rehema Samuel is a charcoal dealer in Mombasa's Mikoroshoni area. She started her business four years ago and it has been a success. She is the mother of three children and is married to Festus Baya.

Rehema is now borrowing her first loan from KADET and she plans to invest the money massively into her business by adding more stock of charcoal.

Rehema was introduced to KADET by an existing member and she joined their group. She mainly serves the residents of Mikoroshoni and the surrounding small-scale traders.

Rehema hopes to expand into a wholesaler in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Renante

texts.en: Renante, 30 years old, lives by farming. He is married and has three children. His farm is the only source of income his family has, so he makes sure to keep his farm healthy for rice crops. He spends the whole day on the farm and although it is tiring, he still enjoys doing it. He is now preparing his land for planting. He he needs materials for the farm, so he applied to CEVI. He is asking for a loan of Php 6,000. He will use this loan to buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Barciliso

texts.en: 60-year-old Barciliso doesn’t mind his age; he still tends his rice farm to support his family financially. He said that for him, he is still strong enough to be working at the farm. He is now preparing his land for planting. He needs inputs for his farm so that he can have an abundant harvest. He applied to CEVI and is requesting a loan of Php 6,000. With this money, Barciliso will be able to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs that he needs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria joined CEVI in January. She wants to avail herself of its financial services because she needs additional capital for her rice farm. She is 58 years old, married, and has eight children. She owns a hectare of rice field, which she and her husband maintain. The farm still needs supplies, so she is requesting a loan of Php 6,000. This loan will go far towards buying farm supplies like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Julita

texts.en: Forty-three-year-old Julita is a rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She is thankful she has a business she can earn money with. Her rice farm provides her family with food to eat, clothes to wear, and their other daily needs. She hopes to grow the farm to earn more so that her family’s living conditions can be improved. She has requested a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to acquire seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies that she is lacking.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Fedila

texts.en: Fedila has three children, whom she sends to school. She is 45 years old and married. She has a rice farm as a source of income. She spends most of her time on the farm just to make sure it is free of weeds and pests, and that her crops are healthy. She wants all her children to finish college and have a bright future. She joined CEVI and applied for a loan of Php 6,000. She has told CEVI that the loan would be used for farm supplies like fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Delgie

texts.en: Delgie manages a hectare of rice field in her home town in Agusan Del Sur. When not busy on the farm, she spends her time running her small store. She thanks God for the sources of income that she currently has. Like any other mother, she wants the best for her family. Delgie recently joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines. She requested a loan of Php 6,000. This is her first time asking for a loan. If it is granted, she will use the loan to buy farm supplies like fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa, 35, is a married woman with two children. Her oldest child is only 14 years old. Both of her children go to school. She works hard to sustain their education and her family’s needs. She manages a rice field, which she said had a good harvest the last time. In order to have an even bigger harvest she has applied to CEVI for financial assistance. She is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 to fund her farm. With this amount, she will be able to buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene Z. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Rene is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Rene owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling coconut sap in the local community as well as making it into coco wine, locally known as "tuba". Rene has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Rene is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru: Бобобекова Малика проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 22 года. Не замужем. Она живет вместе с радителями. У нее среднее образование. Малика более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно- рогатый скот. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Malika B. lives in the district of Yavan. She is 22 years old, not married, and lives with her parents. Malika has high-school education, and for over five years she has been working in the livestock business as a cattle-breeder. She is asking for a loan in order to increase the headcount of her livestock.

Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle for breeding

loans.name: Cruz

texts.es: Cruz S. B. de 56 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Mejicanos, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive únicamente junto a su hija, la cual se dedica a estudiar y a ayudarle a la señora Cruz en el negocio. Cruz posee una venta de frutas y verduras la cual esta ubicada a las afueras del mercado de Mejicanos. Desde hace 30 años que ella se gana la vida de esta manera, venta la cual le permitió comprar su propia casa y poder brindarle todo lo necesario a su hija. La señora Cruz solicita un préstamo  por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar frutas y verduras por mayor, así mismo necesita contar con este dinero ya que ella realiza las compras al contado, ya que de esta forma ella puede obtenerlas a menores precios, lo cual le da una gran ventaja. Cruz desea seguir adelante con su negocio, ya que hasta la fecha las ventas se mantienen estables, así mismo es la única fuente de ingresos con la que cuenta, ya que tanto ella como su hija trabajan en este negocio para sobrevivir.
texts.en:
Cruz S. B., 56, lives in Mejicanos, San Salvador department. He lives with her daughter, who is a student, and who helps her with her business. Cruz is a fruit and vegetable merchant outside the Mejicano’s market. She has earned her livelihood in this way for 30 years. The business provided enough for her to be able to buy her own house and to provide everything her daughter needed. Cruz is asking for funding to buy fruit and vegetables at wholesale. She especially needs the money because she pays cash in order to get better prices, which is an advantage. Cruz hopes to continue with this business because, to date, sales are stable and this is her only source of income; both she and her daughter work to survive.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetable at wholesale.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine A. owns and manages a small sari-sari store business. She has nine children and desires to have a very stable business for her entire family. She has been a client of Community Economic Ventures Inc three times and she wants to take out more loans from CEVI because at 2% per month it has the lowest interest rate. She would like to request a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Lucena Guisihan Group

texts.en:
Lucena G. is from the village of Poblacion, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old. Lucena is the group leader for a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lucena is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucena owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Lucena has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lucena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Lucena is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucena from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her immediate family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily started farming on a small parcel of land. She said that she believed that it would grow well if she works hard on it. She plans to grow her farm to earn better.

Emily is a 34-year-old married woman with a 7-year-old child. She lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She also wants to save for her child’s future.

Emily joined CEVI hoping to have financial assistance. She requested Php 6,000 which she will use to buy farm inputs such fertilizer and seeds. Receiving this loan is truly useful for Emily’s farming.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Gulduzi Group

texts.en:
This is Gulduzi group which has three members: Waisuldin, Naze Gul and Waroky Bib who each have a different business.

Waisuldin is the group leader. He is 22 years old and is married with three children: two sons and one daughter. He is a tailor and has a sewing machine but it is too old and currently is not working properly. He wants to buy a new sewing machine as this is the only business which, through its income, supports his family.

The second member of this group is Naze Gul. She is a embroiderer and wants to buy cloth and other necessary things. Through her income she supports her husband and children.

The last member of this group is Waroky Bibi who runs a business making quilts. She wants to buy cotton, cloth and other essential materials.

Therefore they together have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani to expand their businesses and complete the requirements of their families. They are thankful for all the Kiva lenders and AFSG. Because of these loans they can improve their lives, have better health, and can buy good quality food.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha A. is currently in the business of selling cooked food in a hotel (restaurant) and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer, sodas and water to sell. Asha is 50 years old and is widowed. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar and educate her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer, sodas and water to sell

loans.name: María Del Rosario

texts.es: María del Rosario M. D. U. D. 39 años D. edad, resiD. en Santo Tomás, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador, vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como comerciante, y junto a sus dos hijas D. 13 y 7 años D. edad. Ella posee un puesto D. comida, el cual esta ubicado en el mercado Central D. San Salvador, uno D. los mercados más grandes D. la capital salvadoreña. María se encarga D. elaborar desayunos y almuerzos, contando con mucha clientela quien llega todos los días a degustar D. los deliciosos platillos D. María, los cuales tras 13 años D. experiencia le han permitido ir mejorando y obteniendo más clientes. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda obtener el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad D. granos básicos, verduras, bebidas y otros elementos más para la elaboración D. la comida. María y su familia dependen en gran manera D. este negocio, ya que las ganancias D. su esposo no dan a bastos con todos los gastos del hogar, es por esto que María desea seguir creciendo con su negocio.
texts.en:
María del Rosario M. D. U. is 39 years old and lives in Santo Tomás which is located in the department of San Salvador. She lives with her husband, who works as a storekeeper, and their two children ages 13 and 7. She owns a food stall which is located in the Central San Salvador market, one of the largest markets in the Salvadorian capitol. María makes breakfasts and lunches, and has many customers who come every day to sample her delicious meals. She has 13 years of experience making them, which has allowed her to improve and get more customers. She is requesting a loan in order to get the necessary money to buy a large quantity of staple grains, vegetables, drinks and other ingredients for making food. María and her family greatly depend on this business because her husband's earnings aren't enough to cover their daily expenses. It is for this reason that María wants to continue developing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Fanning, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy staple grains, vegetables and drinks

location.town: Santo Tomás, departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda, 48, is a resident of Banga, South Cotabato, and is a rice farmer. She manages a one-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field which is her main source of living. She has four children to support, the eldest being 28 years old.

Minda lacks capital and that's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 10,000 Php. This loan will help her a lot in providing fertilizer for her rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
With a one-hectare (2.5-acre) rice field, Nestor plants rice. He is 52 years old and lives in Banga, South Cotabato. He has two children, the youngest being 23.

Nestor joins in micro-financing because it helps him develop his business. He's now requesting a loan of 15,000 Php, enough to provide farm inputs. He started his business in 1998 and wants his business to grow. This loan will be helpful since it has a low interest rate.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas, 55, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. He started farming in 1985. Now he manages a 1-hectare rice field. He takes good care of two children in his family; the eldest is 21. He wants his children to have a bright future, that's why he works hard on the farm in order to provide for their needs.

He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, in order to take a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos. He lacks capital and sought help from CEVI. This loan will help in providing fertilizers for his farm.

loans.use: Fertilizers

loans.name: Rakaya

texts.en:
Rakaya E. is currently in the business of selling pancakes in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use to make more cakes to sell. Rakaya is 45 years old and married to a peasant. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more materials to use to make more cakes to sell

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva F., 41, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she earns well so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own mineral water refilling station and food stall, where her main product is breakfast fare.

Minerva has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her food business.     

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by refilling mineral water containers and buying supplies needed for her business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow, enabling her to save enough for her children’s education and proper health and nutritional needs. She has always dreamed of having her own restaurant in the near future too.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Refilling mineral water containers and buying supplies for her business

loans.name: Perla

texts.en: Perla, 64, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. She needs farm inputs to operate her rice field, but she lacks capital. That's why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will enable her to provide the supplies needed for her farm. Perla is the mother of seven children. Rice farming is the only way she can provide for the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: Farm inputs

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en: Rice farming is the main source of income for Romeo, 42. He has two children; the eldest is 20. He said that in his business, he makes a profit but sometimes it's just enough to provide for their daily needs. He does not have enough capital to provide farm supplies. He joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, and requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will enable him to operate his business well and have a good harvest in the future.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Maria Lumosad Group

texts.en: Maria L. is from the village of Puntod, Lopez Jaena. She is 45 years old. Maria is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Maria L.. Maria is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2004, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maria is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Maria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is a 34 year-old rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. The one hectare rice field she manages is her main source of income. She has two children to support, the eldest is ten years old. 

She lacks capital, so she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 15,000 PHP. This loan will help her a lot in providing fertilizers for her rice field.

loans.use: fertilizers for her rice field

loans.name: Luz Margarita

texts.es: Luz Margarita M. R. de 31 años de edad, reside en el Municipio de San Martín, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador. Vive en casa propia, junto a su esposo y dos hijos de 7 y cuatro años de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Luz posee una tortillería y una pupusería, la cual esta ubicada en su casa de habitación. Cada mediodía se encarga de elaborar las tortillas, las cuales cuentan con mucha demanda por el hecho de ser parte de la dieta salvadoreña. Así mismo por las tarde elabora pupusas, las cuales son un platillo muy típico de este país. Luz solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en la compra de más maíz, y así mismo comprar otros ingredientes como queso, frijoles y chicharrón, los cuales son para las pupusas. Luz es una mujer muy trabajadora quien se esfuerza día con día por obtener ganancias las cuales sean de beneficio para su familia.
texts.en:
Luz Margarita M. R., 31, lives in the municipality of San Martín, located in the San Salvador department. She lives in her own home with her husband and two children who are 7 and 4 years old and who study in school. Luz has a business making and selling tortillas and pupusas from her home. Each day at midday she makes the tortillas, for which there is a strong demand as they are a staple of the Salvadoran diet. In addition, in the afternoon she makes pupusas, a dish very typical of this country. Luz requests a loan that she will use to buy more corn and other ingredients such as cheese, beans and pork rinds for the pupusas. Luz is a hardworking woman who strives each day to earn money for the benefit of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy corn, cheese, beans and pork rinds

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma S., 33, is making sure that her family has enough to meet their daily needs. Married to Levi S., a driver, they are blessed with four children. She works so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling ready-to-wear clothing for 12 years. 

Emma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than 2 years. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow eight times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her clothing business.     

Now with your help, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to expand her business by buying additional products that she can sell.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can have a good and comfortable life with her family and provide a good education for her children. She also dreams of having her own stall or outlet where she can sell her products.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying additional clothing that she can sell

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret J. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of onions to sell. Forty years old and married to a retired soldier, Margrethe has seven children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and open a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of onions to sell.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena L., 61, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. A widow blessed with two children, she makes sure that she earns well so that the family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for 10 years now.

Magdalena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for four years now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and paying her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has so far been able to borrow 12 times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her variety store.
