Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 20,000 loan to be used as a source of additional capital for expanding her business by buying stocks to replenish her products. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her family’s daily needs and enjoy a healthy life with them. She also wants to have her own stall where she can sell additional products.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy stocks to replenish her products for her business.

loans.name: Dudu

texts.en:
Dudu E., currently in the business of selling groundnuts at the market, is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts to make paste to sell. Dudu is 50 years old and a widow with eight children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and construct houses for renting.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes M., from the village of Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental,  is 34 years old, married, and has one school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store that sells a variety of products in the local community. Ma. Lourdes is just starting this business.

In 2008, Ma. Lourdes joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her third from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her child. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: V Hamoner's Group

texts.en:
Vilma H., from the village of Matugas Alto, is the 38-year-old group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is V H.'s Group.

Vilma, who is married and has seven school-aged children, owns and operates a clothing business that provides general clothing services to local community members. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month. In 2009, Vilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC, Vilma is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her second from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Fishmonger B Angei Koncy Group

texts.en: A. Koncy is a married business lady. She is 28 years old, with three children. All of her children are going to school and she has two other dependents schooling too. She sells fish, which she has been doing for over seven years. Due to inadequate capital, she is using the loan to purchase fish from the fishermen to sell to her customers. She is adding capital to purchase a big quantity of fish to market. She is a hardworking business lady whose future hopes are to improve and expand her business and her family's welfare.

loans.use: To purchase fish from the fishermen to sell to her customers

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph O., 37 years old, is from Nyalenda town in Kisumu city. He is married to Pamela Anyango, who is a charcoal dealer, and they have four children. Their eldest child is 13 years old and has just joined high school, while the last-born is 6 years old and in primary school.

Joseph is a carpenter. He has been in this business for the last 12 years. He is currently looking for lenders to fund him through Kadet Limited so that he can add more stock to his business, i.e. timber, nails, boards and wires. This is the first loan that he will be getting from us (Kadet) and we have the confidence that he will be able to pay back well since he is committed to the group meetings and has been saving well.

He is good at making good quality beds and sofa sets. This has given him a huge clientele in that area. Besides doing carpentry work, Joseph has two rickshaws, which he uses as means of transport and as his secondary business.

Joseph is planning to pay off the current loan and request a bigger one that can enable him to buy another rickshaw.

loans.use: Buy more materials like timber, nails and wires

loans.name: Fishmonger B Akumu Joyce Group

texts.en: Joyce A. is this group's representative. She is a business lady of 29. She is married with four children, all going to school, and she takes care of one other dependent who is also in school. She sells fish and this has been her business for over five years. Due to insufficient capital, she is using the loan to add capital and purchase a big stock of fish for sale. She is a promising business lady whose dream is to improve on her family’s welfare.

loans.use: To add capital and purchase a stock of fish for sale

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: Alicia, 48, is a rice farmer in Surallah, South Cotabato. She also owns a sari-sari store as a  source of additional income for her family. A mother of three children, the eldest 14 years old, Alicia started her business in 2008. She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for 10,000 Php. This will enable her to buy farm supplies and groceries for her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and groceries

loans.name: Cornelio

texts.en: Cornelio, 40, has been a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato, since 1986, and he now manages a one-and-a-half hectare rice field.  The father of three children, the eldest 19, he wants his children to have a bright future.  That is why he works hard on the farm.  Cornelio joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in order to avail a loan of 10,000 Php in order to buy fertilizer for his farm.

loans.use: Fertilizer

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Corn farming and hog raising are the businesses of Editha. She is 61 years old and is from Surallah, South Cotabato. She's the mother of seven children. She owns two hectares of corn field and one pig. Her business runs smoothly, especially when it's raining. She meets all her needs from her farm business.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase feed and farm supplies. This way she can help provide the needs of her family.

loans.use: feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine I., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Segismundo I., a rice dealer, and they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been a rice dealer for two years now.

Josephine has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow four times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her rice business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to continue to buy and sell rice and thus sustain the business. 

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can help other people by providing cheap rice for them to buy, especially now that the economy is bad. She also wants her children to have a good life and finish their education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to sustain the rice business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine N., 34, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Ricardo N., a driver, they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her variety store for two years now.

Josephine has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 15,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, allowing her to continue buying goods to sell and thus sustaining her variety store. 

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can renovate their house and buy necessary furniture. She also wants her children to finish their education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to sustain her variety store

loans.name: Arsenia

texts.en:
Arsenia S., 60, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Melencio S., a carpenter, they are blessed with eight children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been a fruit/vegetable/meat/fish dealer for 25 years now.

Arsenia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow ten times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a 17,000 PHP loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by allowing her to buy products needed to increase her inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow. Someday soon she wants to have her own business building where she can sell her products wholesale. She also wants her family to have a personal relationship with the Lord like she does.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Samnang's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Samang Y. is a married woman who lives in Krang Pou village, Takeo province. She is the leader of a five-member group loan offered by AMK, one of Kiva's field partners. The couple has three children between the ages of three and nine. Two of their children are currently in the local school. 
She and her husband are farmers who own a one-hectare field to grow crops in order to provide for the family's needs. In order to support the condition of the field, Mrs. Samang Y. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Orubu 1 Layado Esther Group

texts.en: L. Esther is the leader of her group. She is forty-two years old, married, and has eleven children, five of whom are going to school. She is taking care of two additional dependents who are also in school. She sells produce and she has been in this business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase produce like beans and tomatoes to sell. The loan is adding to her previous stock. She is active and encouraging. Her future hope is to build a house and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase produce to sell.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean, 42, a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requested a loan of 12,000 PHP as additional capital for her business of corn farming. She tills a one-hectare corn field in Surallah, South Cotabato. She maintains the farm very well in order to have a plentiful harvest. 

She started corn farming in 1968. She now has two children, and her eldest is fifteen years old. With corn farming, she was able to provide the basic needs of her family. This loan will help a lot to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Elma Cale Group

texts.en:
Elma C. is from the village of Katipunan, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old. Elma is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elma is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Elma has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $100 a month from this activity.

In 2008, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Elma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Orubu 1 Apiyo Rosemary Group

texts.en: A. Rosemary is a business woman, forty-seven years old and married. She has two children in school and is looking after two additional dependents who are also in school. She deals with produce, selling beans, peas, and so on. She is requesting a loan to purchase more produce to sell. She is a promising business woman whose dream is to educate her children, and she works very hard for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase produce to sell.

loans.name: Samoeun Mang Group

texts.en:
Samoeun M. is a group village bank loan which consists of five people located in Thkov village, Takeo province. The loan will be used by the members for different purposes, such as to buy supplies, equipment, or other items,
          
Mrs. Samoeun M. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare field to grow crops. Although she tries to work hard on her farm, she still earns less revenue than she needs to support the family. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for raising pigs. With this loan, she hopes to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living, too. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is a student in the local school while the younger one is only two years old.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline V. is a 58-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling fish. She lives in Brgy. Vito in Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband, Diego. She also helps to manage his piggery. They have five children who are 26 to 37 years old: three of them are currently working. Evangeline has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1994 and has improved her living conditions by her own efforts and with the help of loans from NWTF. By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Evangeline is now borrowing 19,500 PHP for additional business capital. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Evangeline hopes to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Leonora Narvasa Group

texts.en: Leonora N.'s main source of income comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in her community. She is 38 years old, married and has three school-children. They are from the village of Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. Leonora has been in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 4,600 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2006, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 6th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support immediate members of her family. Leonora is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Industrial Area 2 Akoko Margaret Group

texts.en: A. Margaret represents this group. She is an active business woman whose business is dealing in produce: maize, beans, g-nuts (peanuts), etc. She has been in this business for over 16 years. Due to inadequate capital, she needs a loan to purchase goods and increase her stock. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to educate her children and improve the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase produce

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en: Nieves A. is a 62-year-old married woman who lives in Nabantu-an, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Nieves’s husband, Victoriano, is 61 years old and helps his wife run the store. They have seven children between 28 and 45 years old. Some of the children are married with children of their own and most are working. Nieves joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1984 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income with her general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her business activities. Nieves is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and her family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 20th loan, in the amount of 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store. Nieves is working hard to achieve her dream for her family which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en: Wilma P. owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in her community. She is 40 years old, married and has four adult children. She is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Wilma has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 1,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to to purchase products to sell. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support extended members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 39-year-old woman, married with three children. Her eldest child is 18 years old. She is happy because her children are excelling in school. She sells baby things and sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for 14 years. With the proceeds from her business, she can now help her husband meet the basic needs of their family. She hopes to acquire a bigger store and expand her business in future. She needs a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more baby things and sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baby things and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Nelma

texts.en: Nelma T. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a fish vending business. She lives in Brgy 4, Menez St., Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental, with her husband, Romeo, and their three children, all of whom are school age. Nelma has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2001 and has improved her living conditions through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. By working hard in her general store and fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Nelma is now borrowing 19,500 PHP so that she can buy additional inventory for her businesses. This will be her 10th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Nelma hopes to improve her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Phall

texts.en: Mr. Phall P. is 56 years old and lives in Sam raong village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Srey Nou Par, are farmers who own a 3-hectare field where they grow crops. They now face a problem because the soil is infertile. Mr. Phall P. is, therefore, requesting 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to purchase fertilizer and pesticide. As well as farming, he works as a laborer and can earn a small income to support his family. The couple have four children. Three are students in the local school while the youngest one is too young to study or work. His wife is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita J. is a 51-year-old married woman who lives in Nabantu-an 1, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating an auto repair shop.

Elenita’s husband, Elmer, is also 51.  He manages a junk shop business.  Together they have 4 children aged between 10 and 23.  Three of the children go to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.  The oldest is currently working.

Elenita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1990 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by operating the auto repair business. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities.

Elenita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 17,000 was used to fund operations of her auto repair shop business. It had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 20th loan of Php 17,000, which she intends to use on the junk shop business. Elenita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Athel

texts.en: Athel is a very good business woman; she sells sarongs at retail prices to her customers in Sapele, Delta. She is a hard working woman and works for long hours so that she can meet the basic needs of her family. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is happily married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 21 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. Athel’s husband is self employed and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
Flor M. is a married woman. She supports her family by selling vegetables and dried fish and operating an eatery business. She lives in Prk Everlasting, Escalante City Negros Occidental with her husband and their one child, who is 31 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004. With the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts, she has improved her living conditions. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000.

Flor is now borrowing Php 25,000 to use as additional capital for her business. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Flor aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly E. is a 42 year old, married woman who lives in Pou Bay village, Takeo province. She earns a living through her general store while her husband, Mr. Kim Eng E., is a farmer. They have two children, one of whom supports the parents while the other one is a student in the local school.                 
Mrs. Ly E. is a grocer who can earn a small income to support her family. She wants to expand her business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more groceries to sell. With this loan she will increase her income and improve the living conditions of her family.
Her husband is in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for resale

loans.name: Industrial Area 2 Oyella Christine Group

texts.en: Christine O. is a hardworking businesswoman of 40. She is a widow with three children and she has three other dependents in school. She owns a charcoal store and has been dealing in the charcoal business for over five years. Since she could not get charcoal herself from villages, she could only obtain poor quality charcoal, which made her lose customers. But now she is using the loan to purchase charcoal from villages herself to sell in her store. She is a hardworking businesswoman who dreams of increasing her business and educating her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal from villages to sell in her store

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en: Diosdada M. is a 49-year-old married woman living in Brgy. Quezon, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by planting rice and vegetables for sale. Diosdada’s husband, Protacio, is 48 years old and makes his living as a farmer. They have eight children between the ages of 5 and 26 years old. Three of her children already have families of their own and the other five are in her custody. Some of her children are currently going to school and also helping their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. Diosdada joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 with the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income and earns an average monthly income of 4,000 Philippine pesos from her business activities. Diosdada is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 11,000 was used to fund operations of her rice and vegetables plantation, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing, for her 11th loan, the amount of Php 12,000 to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. Diosdada is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Ola

texts.en: Ola is a hard working woman and she is determined to excel in her business. She is a hair stylist and she makes lovely Nigerian and western hairstyles for her customers. She also sells hair extensions and hair cream in her salon. She hopes to own a world-class hair salon in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more hair materials to sell. She is married to a businessman who supports his home. She has two children. The youngest child is 4 years old. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair materials to sell.

loans.name: Romelyn

texts.en:
Romelyn D. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing business and running a general store. She lives in Talusan Brgy Bulanon in Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her 39-year-old husband Ronnie, who makes his living as a fisherman. Together, they have three children between 3 and 16 years old.
Romelyn has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 2000. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP.
Romelyn is now requesting to borrow 19,500 PHP as additional capital for her fishing and general store businesses. This will be her ninth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Romelyn aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure its future well-being by following the 'Dungganon' way.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou C. is from the village of Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Marilou is separated from her spouse and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

With the help of her loans from AMK, she has been able to increase her income and the family improves from her business activities.

loans.name: Rahmon

texts.ru: Лолаев Рахмон проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 57 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Дети живут отдельно. У него возле своего дома есть магазин. Он продает продукты и хозяйственные товары. Рахмон одновременно занимается животноводством. В этой деятельности он более 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Rahmon L. lives in the Yavan district. He is 57 years old, married and has 7 children. His wife is a homemaker. The children live separately. Rahmon has a store near his house, where he sells food products and household goods. He is also involved in animal husbandry. He has been in this business for over 20 years. Rahmon is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle in order to increase their quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Liberto

texts.en: Liberto P. is from the village of Colupan Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. He is 58 years old, married, and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Liberto owns & operates a business manufacturing & selling hollow block products to local businesses and community members. Liberto has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2008, Liberto joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liberto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Liberto is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Liberto from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

The couple has three children between the ages of 8 and 24. Two of their children are currently employees in the garment factory while the youngest one is a student in the local school. His wife is O. the right in the picture.

Eliada M. is a 52-year-old married woman living in Brgy Quezon, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by planting vegetables for sale.

Eliada’s husband, Edgardo, is 55 years old and a farmer.  Together they have nine children, who are between 9 and 33 years old.  Three of her children already have a family, and some of her children are currently going to school.  The children living at home also help their parents with the business as part of their daily chores.

texts.en: Mawuli Y. was born in Kpalimé, Togo, a town two hours north of the country’s capital. She is 36 years old and now lives and works in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo. Mrs. Y. runs a grocery store called “Etablissement Manu,” which she began in 2004. She often purchases her stock at the Grand Marché of Lomé and sells her products to a variety of customers in her neighborhood. Mrs. Y. is now asking for her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to replenish her stock. Specifically, she plans on purchasing cooking oil, rice, cosmetics and other diverse products. With this loan, Mrs. Y. will be able to further contribute to the daily expenses of her husband and two children.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny D. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Prk 8, Lacson, Valladolid, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and a vegetable-vending business. Jenny's husband, Rosauro, is 41 years old and works as both a farmer and a trader of scrap iron. They have three children who currently go to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.
Jenny joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2007 with the hope of helping her husband to improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF, she has been able to increase the family income by engaging in her general store and vegetable-vending businesses. Now she earns an average monthly income of 12,000 PHP from her business activities.
Jenny is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP was used to fund the operation of both her businesses. It had a positive impact on both the businesses and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her sixth loan, of 18,000 PHP, which she will use to buy additional inventory for her store and as capital for her vegetable-vending business. Jenny is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.
