Bombills, Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband Rodrigo, who is 53 years old.  She has six children, two of whom are adults.  The remaining four are currently attending school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and eatery business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $150.

Myrna is now borrowing 13,000 PHP so that she can buy supplies and inventory for the general store and eatery. This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Myrna aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy supplies and restock inventory

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Rorn K. is 55 years old, married and lives in Thnuoh village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chin Mao are farmers who own a piece of land to cultivate rice. Although, they work hard with in the fields they earn a very low income with which they support their family. Thus, Mrs. Rorn K. began a new business is grocery seller. In order to support this business, she is requesting a loan of 1,600,000 Riel from AMK to buy groceries to support this  business. With this loan she hopes to increase her income and improve the family living. 

Mrs. Rorn K. is a mother of six children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory and another one in construction. The other children are at home and supported by their parents. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy groceries for resale

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda O. is from the village of  Mambajao, Camiguin province. She is 54 years old. Rosalinda is widowed and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling electronic load (all networks)in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is a happy woman and is always prepared to serve her customers better. She hopes to receive a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. She hopes to be a major engine oil distributor in the future. 

Rita is a widow with 4 children. Alone, she takes care of her 4 children and she hopes they become graduate from school soon. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida S. is a 59-year-old married woman who lives in Bateria, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns a living by operating a ready-to-wear business. In this type of business, a popular one in the community, she buys and sells used clothing. Her husband, Gregorio, is 60 years old and stays at home as he is sick. They have six children between the ages of 29 and 40 years old. Some of the children have their own families, while the remaining children work to support the family, especially their sickly father.
Adelaida joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 1996 in the hope of helping her husband to improve the family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF, she has been able to increase the family income by running her ready-to-wear business. Now, she earns an average monthly income of 6,000 PHP from her business activities.
Adelaida is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP was used to fund the operation of her ready-to-wear business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now, she is borrowing her thirteenth loan, of 17,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional inventory for her business. Adelaida is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Y

texts.en:
Mrs.Y U. is 38 years old, married, and lives in Trapeang Snao village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Heng Nget is a construction worker. Together, they make a small income to support their family.  

Mrs. Y U. is requesting a  2,000,000 from AMK to buy two oxen to help with farming the crops. The couple has four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other three attend the local school. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy two oxen to help with the farming

loans.name: Olailong B Acan Night Group

texts.en:
A. Night is a hardworking businesswoman and leader of her small group of six members. She is twenty-five years old and married with three children who are schooling.

Night is dealing in a business selling local brew and she has been operating this type of business for over three years. But due to insufficient capital, she is using the loan to purchase and stock millet, sorghum and so forth for her local brew business.

The loan is improving Night’s business whereby she hopes to enlarge her business for better profits.

loans.use: To purchase and stock millet, sorghum and so forth for her local brew business

loans.name: Aïchetou

texts.en:
Aïchetou G. M. is 26 years old and a trained nurse. She works in the Agoé district of Lomé, Togo and is married with one child.

Mrs. M. runs a clinic and pharmacy called “Cabinet Médical Mawuli” which she began in 2008. She is able to serve a variety of patients in her immediate area.

Mrs. M. is now asking for her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock of medical supplies and pharmaceuticals. Please help Mrs. M. replenish her supply and better serve her patients.

loans.use: To purchase more pharmaceuticals and medical supplies

loans.name: Olailong B Arach Dorine Group

texts.en:
A. Dorine is the group representative of five members in her group. She is thirty-seven years old, married, and blessed with three children all going to school. More so, she looks after two dependents, both schooling, too.

Dorine has operated a local brew business so far for ten years. Although the business seem to be seasonal in most cases, she is using the loan to improve her business by stocking much millet and sorghum for making local brew. This is helping her to improve on her standard of living.

loans.use: To improve her business by stocking much millet and sorghum for making local brew

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella loves groceries and that is why she sells them to make a living. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell.

Stella is 35 years old and married with five children, her eldest being 14 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. She hopes to see her children become graduates in the future.

Stella says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Daim's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Daim N. is the village bank leader of a group that consists of four people located in Prey Phdau Cheung village, Takeo province. The group members will all use the loan to buy supplies and other items for different purposes.

Mrs. Daim N. is a silk weaver who is able to earn a small income to support her family. In order to expand her business and increase her income, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk to support her silk-weaving.

Mrs. Daim N.’s husband, Mr. Orn Men, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice. This couple has four children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory while the last one is supporting them.

loans.use: To buy more silk for her silk-weaving business

loans.name: Vardan

texts.en:
Vardan G. was born in 1979 and lives in Aghavnavank village, in the Ljevan area. He is married and has a daughter. Vardan has a good education and is a teacher. He has worked as a teacher in the Aghavnavanq village school and is alos a secretary in the village municipality. Part time he is engaged in livestock farming with his family. 

Last year Vardan had to leave his job with the village municipality because of the heavy farm work load. Now he works as a teacher and  in stock-breeding. Vardan says that stock-breeding is very hard work but also a very profitably business. With his profit from farming he provides for his family’s needs. 

Vardan has requested a loan of 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy a car to provide an easier life for his family.

loans.use: To buy a car

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 76 years old and married with eight adult children between the ages of 23 and 50.

Samson is a farmer near Kisii in south-western Kenya and has been farming for thirty years. He grows tea and sells it through the Kenya Tea Development Agency. He says that the main challenge to his business is accessing a market for his goods.

Samson requested this loan of Kes 42,000 through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This will allow him to have milk for sale and for family consumption, improving his family's health. He believes it will also allow him to create employment for others. In the future, he says that he hopes to have good dairy cows for quality and quantity milk production.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bak

texts.en:
Mr. Bak K. is 45 years old and lives in Kakaoh village, Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Long K., are farmers who own a piece of land on which they cultivate rice to earn a living. They are shown together in the photo.

With this farming, they still earn less income than needed to support their family. So Mr. Bak K. is requesting a 2,000,000 Riel loan from AMK to buy two cows for breeding. With the loan, his income will be increased which will improve his family living, too.

This couple has four children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory, another one is supporting their farming while the other two are attending the public school.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding

loans.name: Mohammad Arif

texts.en:
Mohammad Arif, 37 years old, is married and is the father of four children. He lives in district 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan.

Mohammad has a photo shop and he has had good experience for more than four years in his business. He has already successfully completed his first loan and expanded his stock.

Still, Mohammad wants to further expand his business with full success, so now he has requested his second loan to enlarge his shop so as to attract more customers and make a good income to help his family. He is happy with this process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy some necessary things for his shop

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita A. is a married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing and fish-vending business. Her 57-year-old husband, Rogelio, is a fisherman and whatever he catches, she sells to her community. Margarita lives in Talusan Brgy. Bulanon, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their four children aged between 22 and 27. One child already has a family, and the rest are working.
Margarita has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 1992. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing and fish-vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 11,000 PHP.
Margarita is now borrowing 29,500 PHP to buy a new fishing net and materials to repair her pump boat. This will be her sixteenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Margarita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the 'Dungganon' way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy a fishing net and materials to repair her fishing boat

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli T., a 58-year old married woman who lives in Brgy Talusan, Sagay City, Negros Occidental, earns her living by buying and selling vegetables. Araceli’s husband Mauriceo is 61 years old and works as a coconut sap extractor (Mananggete). They have ten children, eight of whom have their own families while two still live at home but are also gainfully employed and contribute toward the support of their household.

Arceli joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by buying and selling vegetables. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 10,000 from her business activities.

Araceli is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 19,500 was used to fund her vegetable-vending business, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 12th loan in the amount of Php 19,500 to buy more vegetables to resell. Araceli is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Olialong B Aciro Betty Group

texts.en:
A. Betty is the group representative of the eight members in this group. She is a hardworking businesswoman of thirty-eight years, married and blessed with five children schooling.

Betty sells fish and she has been doing this for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase more fish and also cassava to sell.

Betty encourages the group members to work very hard to change the standard of living of their families as well their lives. She is active and courageous. Her future hope is to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more fish and also cassava to sell

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en:
To earn a living in Sapele, Ngozi sells cellophane bags at retail prices to her customers (cellophane  is a thin, transparent sheet made of regenerated cellulose and is used for food packaging). She is a hardworking woman and she is so determined to lift her business and family above poverty.

Ngozi hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more cellophane bags to sell. In the future she hopes to be a major cellophane bag distributor in major markets in her community.

Ngozi is 49 years old and married with five children who are excelling in their jobs and education. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports the home. Ngozi says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cellophane bags to sell

loans.name: Sambou

texts.en:
Mrs. Sambou H. is 40 years old, married, and lives in Sam Raong village, Takeo province. Her spouse has four children, three of them are students in the local school while the youngest is two years old.                
Mrs. Sambou H. is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Bros Ben, is a cattle middleman. He is able to earn a small income to support his family. In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Sambou H. has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva partner, AMK, to buy two oxen for her husband's business. With her loan, she hopes her income will increase and her family's standard of living will improve.

loans.use: To buy two oxen

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov N. is 30 years old, married, and the mother of two school-aged children. She lives in Chhaom Povpisey village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Tol Mark, are farmers who own a plot of land to grow crops to earn a living. Although they work hard, they still earn insufficient income to support their family. Therefore, Mrs. Pov N. wants to begin a new business breeding pigs. In order to support it, Mrs. Pov N. is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 KHR from Kiva partner, AMK, to purchase piglets for breeding. With the rest of the loan, she will purchase pigs for resale. This loan will allow her to improve living conditions for herself and her family.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and pigs for resale

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 27 years old and married with two school-aged children. He is a farmer near Kisii in south-western Kenya. James has been farming for four years and sells milk, cabbage and tomatoes at the local market and from the farm. He says that the main challenge to his business is low local pricing for his goods.
James has requested a loan through Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 70,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this will help him produce enough milk to sell. He believes that he will also then be able to offer employment to others. In the future, he would like to own a pick-up truck in order to transport his products to market.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is 32 years old, married to a businessman, and has four children. Her youngest child is three years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school.
Blessing sells dried fish to make a living in Sapele. In Nigeria, dried fish is an essential ingredient in the preparation of a local soup like egusi (melon soup), and so demand is high. Blessing loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She sells her dried fish at retail prices to customers. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more dried fish to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhorn M. is 39 years old, married, and lives in Kouk Roka village, Takeo province. She has two children who are students in the public school.  She and her husband, Mr. Bol Ouch, are farmers who earn a living by growing crops on their three-hectare field. In order to support their farm, Mrs. Sokhorn M. is applying for a loan of 1,500,000 KHR from Kiva partner, AMK, to purchase a water machine. With the rest of the loan, she will buy fertilizer and gasoline to maintain the field.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine, fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Gull Mursal Group

texts.en: This is the Gull Mursal group, comprised of three female members led by 33-year-old Nasreen.   Nasreen wants to take a loan for her brother, who sells second-hand dresses and clothes. With this loan he wants to complete his stocks. The second member of  the group is Bibi Maryam who wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a shop that sells bicycles. With this loan he wants to buy some necessary things for his shop. The last member is Fahima, who wants to take a loan for her brother who has a general store. With this loan he wants to buy more foods and tools for his store. They all are happy about this process of small loans in Afghanistan and other poor countries and thank all lenders from both Kiva and AFS.

loans.use: To complete store stocks

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana N. is a happily married mother of four children. Her husband is a businessman who also supports the home. A lady gifted in crafts, Christiana uses locally-made materials to make beads to sell in Sapele, Delta state.  She also sells jewelry at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more jewelry to sell and hopes to own a world-class jewelry shop in the future. Christiana says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Sae

texts.en: Mrs. Sae S. is 54 years old, married and lives in Tralach village, Takeo province. She has two children, both of whom work in a garment factory. She and her husband, Mr. Chin Sai Sor, make a living as farmers. When not farming, Mrs. Sae S. supplements her income by selling groceries. She has applied for loan for 1,300,000 Riel from AMK to enlarge her business by buying more groceries to sell to her customers. This should allow her to satisfy their needs while also improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to her customers

loans.name: Yehlen

texts.en:
Yehlen M. is active in one of our ASHI centers. Since joining our organization, she has applied for and received two loans and successfully repaid both of them. Now she is applying for a new loan, from Kiva and its field partner ASHI, to increase the inventory of her variety or sari-sari store, which she was able to open after receiving her first two loans. 

“Sari-sari” is a Filipino term for variety, and a “sari-sari” store is a small business that sells basic goods. Such stores are located in almost every block of a typical Filipino village. It is also the easiest way for people to earn a little profit without leaving their own home. However, to Yehlen, her store means everything. It is the source of food for her two children, aged three and seven, a way to pay for their education, and a way for her to battle against poverty and for justice for her husband, who is presently in jail. With a hope that someday she will earn enough money to hire a lawyer and free him, Yehlen is determined to grow her business and increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell from her store.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Women in Nigeria love sarongs, and wear ones with lovely designs for many different purposes. Kate loves sarongs too, and that is why she has chosen to make a living selling them. She has been in this business for a long time, and has applied for a loan for N120,000 to buy more sarongs to sell. She is a hard-working woman who is determined to lift her business and her family above poverty, and someday hopes to own a world-class boutique. She is married and has seven children. Her husband makes a living selling wooden planks used in various construction projects. Kate extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more sarongs to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is a widow who has eight children. She is a gifted lady who is very skilled at making items out of beads. She sells these items in her home town of Sapele, in Nigeria's Delta state. She uses local materials to make these items. Beads in Nigeria are worn on many occasions, including weddings, burials and naming ceremonies. They are also worn by Nigeria's titled chiefs, because beads are given much respect in this country. Comfort also sells her wares at retail prices to her customers, and hopes to own a world-class bead shop in the future. She has applied for a loan for NGN 100,000 to buy more of the materials she needs to make beaded items. She extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more materials from which to make beaded items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Set up a corn mill

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Mrs. Sina P. is 45 years old and lives in Thlok Doung Tum village, Takeo province. She is a widow with four children; one of them works in a local garment factory, while the other three are students. All four of her children support her silk-weaving business. Mrs. Sina P. and her family work hard but earn only a small income. That is why Mrs. Sina P. has applied to AMK for a loan for 8,000,000 Riel to buy more silk and supplies. Her goal is to use the loan to increase her output, earn more money, and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more silk and supplies

loans.name: Adorma

texts.en:
Adorma P.’s previous businesses which were established using loans through ASHI, Kiva field partner in the Philippines, have been her great source of income to help her most needy children and grandchildren. At her present age of 57 years old, she still feels her inner capability to run a business and continue helping her children and grandchildren. Therefore she remains active in her membership to ASHI. She repays on time every week and she attends weekly center meetings. Adorma now is requesting another loan to try another kind of business which is tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar attached) for hire, to be managed by her husband who has been a driver for a long time now. 

Tricycle is a Filipino version of a rickshaw and this is the most common means of transportation anywhere in the Philippines, especially in provinces and in its villages. Therefore, with this kind of business, Adorma hopes that someday, she can afford to renovate their house and respond to the expenses incurred by her family. She also likes to save a certain amount for her family’s emergency needs such as hospitalization.

loans.use: To purchase sidecar to be attached to a motorcycle for a tricycle for hire business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy alcoholic beverages

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina loves her business and that is why she hopes to excel in her business. She sells dried fish at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more dried fish to sell. She is married with 5 children, and her youngest child is 12 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Rung

texts.en:
Mrs. Rung M. is 44 years old and she lives in Rung village, Takeo province. She is a married woman with four children, two of whom are employed in the garment factory while the other two are attending the local school. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Nhor Vong, is a cow middleman.
Right now, Mrs. Rung M. is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to support her husband's business by purchasing 4 cows. With the help of her loans from AMK, she has been able to increase the family's income from her husband's business.

loans.use: To purchase 4 cows.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
For the past 33 years of being poor, Nancy R. can hardly remember a time when she was happy and not bothered by her family's economic situation. She can always recall the many struggles she has been through just to have something for her children to eat and survive each day. Beginning in 1999, Nancy became thankful for ASHI, Kiva field partner in the Philippines, because it was through her membership that she accessed a loan which enabled her to start a small business.

She tried several ways to earn money until the amount of loan she could request had increased. With the support of her loving husband and children, Nancy ventured into a business of selling fish and slaughtering pigs. Both are sold from her rented stall at the Municipal market. Eventually, Nancy’s life has changed a bit together with her family. However, she is still financially insecure, especially the thought that her five children aged 1 to 14, are growing and their needs, especially in education, are also increasing. Nancy is scared that the present profit her business is making will not be enough for her to sustain the education of her children until they graduate from college. With that in mind, Nancy now is requesting a much larger amount of loan to expand her business. She and her husband agreed to purchase a mini-truck (multicab in Filipino) so that they can supply fish to their customers in other neighboring provinces and cities around Panay Island (small Island in the Philippines where Antique province is situated).

loans.use: To purchase a mini-truck for the delivery of large volumes of fish.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana loves her business and that is why she hopes to excel in her business. She sells dried fish at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more dried fish to sell. She is married with 3 children, and her youngest child is 15 years old. Her children are exceling in school and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy thread to weave pagnes

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Mrs. Norn M. is 60 years old and she lives in Trapeang Kak village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chrin Oun, are farmers who own a 1.5 hectare field where they grow crops to earn a living for their family. In order to change their living conditions, Mrs. Norn M. decided to ask for a loan to buy 10 piglets and pig food for pig breeding. She hopes the loans will increase the family's income. Mrs. Norn M. is a mother of two children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory, while the other one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy 10 piglets and pig food.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Zarif

texts.en:
Zarif is a 34 year old man, married with two children, who dedicates his time to driving a microbus. His usual itinerary is the Kanibadam-Khujand route. Zarif has about 5 years of experience in the public transportation field, and the competition is rather high in this business since there are so many people who need it. His current request is so that he can maintain his vehicle, since this is the tool of his trade. So now Zarif is counting on your help and requesting a loan of $1200 USD. With the loan he’ll purchase the spare parts for his microbus. With your support, Zarif will continue to progress. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase spare parts in order to repair the microbus.

loans.name: Narimon

texts.en:
Narimon B. is 20 years old. He is a cattleman, who raises cattle to sell. At the same time, Narimon sells dried fruits in the local market. Narimon has been working as a market vendor for 3 years. Thanks to these two businesses, Narimon is able to support his parents with their household expenses. Today, Narimon is going to increase the turnover capital for his business selling dried fruits. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting $3000 US Dollars. The loan will be spent on purchasing dried fruits and cattle for selling. This is the first loan for Narimon, however, he is sure he shall be able to pay it in time and thanks everyone who trusts him with their support.

loans.use: Buy corn and peanuts

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom N. is a 58 year old married woman who lives in Prey Chheu Teal village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vang Kheav, are farmers. She also has a small business as a salt seller and she owns a motorcycle that she uses to resell the salt door-to-door. She does not have enough money to continue expand this business. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan from AMK to purchase more salt for selling. She hopes the loan will be able to increase her income and improve the family's living too.

Mrs. Mom N. is a mother of four children, one of whom is a construction worker and the other three are students in the public school and also help their parents with the farming and the mother with her business. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To purchase more salt.

loans.name: Maksuda

texts.en:
Maksuda D. is 45 years old. She is married, and uses all the money she makes to care for her 4 children and provide for their education. Maksuda has 5 years of experience selling dried fruits. She always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. She is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, she is increasing her net worth month by month. Today, Maksuda requests 4000 Somoni for purchasing dried fruits with the purpose of processing them in order increase the range of her goods for sale. Maksuda expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase dried fruits in order to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Giselle

texts.en:
Giselle is 24 years old and she is still young in marriage. She takes care of one dependent who is 16 years old. Giselle lives in the Nyarugenge district of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Giselle has been in the business of selling raw cloth to her customers so that they can sew trousers, shirts and some other styles. This is her sixth successful year in this business and the hours of her business are from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Giselle needs to expand her business through purchasing cloth of good quality and colors. With this business expansion, she hopes to attract more customers who will come in her shop to purchase her cloth. Once they come, she hopes that her sales will increase as well as her profits.

Giselle has a target of keeping her business financially stable and through her access to this loan, she hopes that her target will be achieved.

loans.use: To purchase cloth of good quality and colors

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat I. is 38 years old. She is married with three children. Muhabbat sells clothing for kids and many other small things. She started her business 15 years ago. At that time her husband-entrepreneur supported Muhabbat, providing the funds for start-up. Gradually, the business of Muhabbat expanded. Being hard-working and polite by nature, she managed to obtain a clientele that is happy with the goods and the services. The business generates a stable income for the family. Muhabbat loves her children very much and she wants all of them to be well-educated. Today, she is requesting 5000 Somoni. She is planning to spend the loan on purchasing additional goods for sale. You could become an important part in Muhabbat family's life. She deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.

loans.use: To purchase men’s clothing to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Roseline is a hard working woman. She is also a friendly woman. She uses her friendly skills to attract and retain customers for her business. She sells sarongs and head gear of various colours and shapes. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to really expand her business. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 40 years old and married with 6 children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok B. is a 40 year old married woman who lives in Pongro village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vang Nget, are farmers who own a 7-hectare field where they grow crops. Because of the dry season, Mrs. Sok B. needs 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to support the farm crop.
 
Aside from being a farmer, Mrs. Sok B. also breeds ducks at home, and earns a small income to support her family's living. The couple has two children, one of whom is a farmer who supports the parents with the farming, while the other one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline.

loans.name: Nigora

texts.en: K. Nigora is 36 years old and is married with three children. Her husband isn’t earning very much so, in order to help her husband and to support her family, Nigora has been running her business already for five years. Nigora sells household appliances and all the equipment is imported from Khujand and Istaravshan. The business generates a significant income for the family allowing improvement in their living conditions. Today Nigora requests 800 US Dollars which she is going to spend on purchasing new household appliances like flatirons, electric ovens, and electric heaters. loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric

loans.name: Chheob

texts.en:
Mrs. Chheob P. is 36 years old and she lives in Moeang Prachen village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 1.3-hectare (3.25-acre) field on which she grows crops. She also raises pigs and is able to earn a small income to support her living.

Mrs. Chheob P. is now requesting loan of 1,000,000 Riel from AMK to enlarge her business and purchase fertilizer to grow more crops. She hopes to earn additional revenue so she can improve the living conditions of her family.

Mrs. Chheob P. is a widow with five children, one of whom is employed in the garment factory while the other four are students in the local school and also help their mother with her work.

loans.use: To enlarge her pig-raising business and purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Rayhana Kharasan Group

texts.en:
Bibi Rayhana is the group leader of Rayhana Kharasan group. She is a 40 -year -old woman married with four children who are in school. She lives in 11 district of Kabul Afhganistan.She has a bakery in her area. She knew about this skill when she was 15 years old becasue her mother had the same business. After marriage she had some economic problems that is why she decided to start the business of bakery. At the begining she had a few clients,but now she is quite famous among her neighbors. She wants to take a loan for her bakery to purchase fire wood and some tools which are necessary for baking the bread.
For her future she hopes to open a new shop and progress her business.

loans.use: purchasing fire wood and tools

loans.name: Ese

texts.en: Ese is a hard working woman. She is also a friendly woman. She uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her business. She sells sarongs of various colours and shapes. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to really expand her business. She hopes for a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 41 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Amaka

texts.en: Amaka sells fruits like apples to make a living in Sapele, Delta state, Nigeria. She loves this business and she sells for long hours to enable her to make more profits to make her business sustainable. She hopes for a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more apples to sell at retail prices to her customers. She is 40 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are excelling in their school work. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more apples to sell.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica sells tubers of yams to earn a living. Yams in Nigeria can be eaten by boiling, frying, pounding or roasting. It is a staple food in Nigeria and Nigerians love yams. Veronica hopes for a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more tubers of yams to sell. She is 50 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a contractor and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell.

loans.name: Ñepytyvo Group

texts.es:
El comité “Ñepytyvo” se formó con la unión varias vecinas del barrio  Villa La Conquista, de la ciudad de Ñemby. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas. 

Las integrantes formaron un grupo  muy unido y capaz de realizar actividades en forma conjunta, ya que la mayoría de sus integrantes se dedican a la venta, siendo así la mayoría de ellas, colegas entre si.
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a dichas actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable.
La Sra. Cayetana R. se dedica a la venta de queso que ella produce a partir de la leche que compra de sus vecinas, pero actualmente recibió muchos pedidos y necesita comprar en gran cantidad para poder abastecer a sus clientes, por ello agradece el préstamos que reciben de la Fundación para llevar a cabo cada sus actividades.

texts.en:
The “Ñepytyvo” committee is made up of a group of neighbors from the Villa la Conquista neighborhood from the city of Ñemby. All of the members are working independently in different activities, such as sales. The members form a united and capable group that work together, with the majority working in sales like their colleagues. All of the members are mothers and the goal of their work is to strengthen their household financially and to develop their businesses in a sustainable manner. Mrs. Cayetana R. sells cheese that she produces from the milk that she buys from her neighbors. Currently she has received many orders and has to buy much more so that she can supply her customers. She is thankful to the foundation for the loan that helps her succeed with her work. The work of each one is listed below: 1 Cayetana R. Selling cheese 2 Sebastian V. Selling food 3 Maria L N. Handicrafts 4 Domiciana S. Selling food 5 Karina E. C. Selling fruit 6 Cornelia V. Selling prepared food 7 Alejandrina T. Selling clothing 8 Eusebia S. Selling chicken 9 Juana S. loans.name: Islom

texts.en:
Islom U. is a married man with two children. His children have been the reason that he tries so hard to provide them with a stable family life and an education for their future. For the past 10 years, Islom has sold foodstuff at the market. This is a profitable business in his neighborhood, and his sales have increased considerably year after year. His start-up capital was from the severance pay he received from where he used to work. To expand his business, Islom is requesting a loan of 6000 Somoni, which he intends to use to increase the range of his goods for sale. The loan will greatly improve Islom’s income and his family's living standards.

Paulina's husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home.Yam is a staple food in Nigeria and it can be eaten for any occasion. He has one employee in his shop who supports him now,but he expects and hopes to grow his buisiness in order to hire one new employee.
