texts.en:
The committee "Nuevo Horizonte" ("New Horizon") was formed by a group of neighbors in the city of San Antonio. All the members of the committee perform indepedent activities, such as sales. The members have formed a very united group capable of realizing activities together, so now the majority of the members work in sales together as colleagues. All the members of the committee are mothers who work developing sustainable businesses in order to support their households. Mrs. Maria M. is a baker, baking items to order for birthdays, quinceañeras, weddings, and other events. She works according to the number of orders she receives from her clients. She herself bakes the goods or has bakeries do it because the orders require ingredients in large quantities. She is grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya for the loan given to each one of the committee's members. 1. Maria M., bakery 2. Digna G., clothes sales 3. Dolores R., clothes sales 4. Dorotea J., kiosk 5. Digna C., cosmetics sales 6. Dora O., sports pool/lottery sales 7. Zunilda C., sports pool/lottery sales 8. Nancy D., beverage sales 9. Zeneida D., snack sales 10. Cirila S., food coupon sales 11. Edelina Alfonzo, baking 12. Mabel C., clothing sales 13. Teresa M., food sales 14. Rosalina G., food coupon sales 15. Ruth A., fruit sales 16. Nancy R., clothing sales 17. Maria E., baking 18. Candida A., cosmetics sales 19. Lucia A., sports pools/lottery sales

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for baking like sugar, butter, eggs, and utensils

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose sells starch in Sapele, Delta state. Starch is a staple food in the Delta part of Nigeria. It is usually eaten with a Nigerian soup called banga soup. This meal is very rich in oil and many Nigerians love this food. 

She hopes for a loan of 70,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more starch to sell. She is a widow with five children. Life as a widow is not easy and Bose sells for long hours to meet the basic needs of her children. She hopes to grow her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more starch to sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 30 years old and is single. He takes care of his parents. He lives in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Samuel’s business is located in the village of Nyarutarama which is a residential place. He owns a small shop selling different kinds of products such as cosmetics products, soaps, plastic shoes, sugar, rice, and so on. He chose this business simply because it is very profitable as well as important for his neighbors.

Samuel has many years of experience but his monthly profit is still too low to expand his business meaningfully. He believes that a small amount of additional capital would change that for him. For that reason, he is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to purchase additional products which will make him more efficient and effective and more successful. He thanks VFC and Kiva lenders for their support!

Samuel is very serious in his business; the hours of his shop are from six in the morning to six in the evening every day except on Saturday and he employs one person so that his business runs well. Samuel expects to obtain more profits which will be used for reinvestment in order to satisfy his customers by offering them enough products at a good price.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Sergyi

texts.en:
Sergyi is married and has a 6-year-old daughter. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk. Sergyi runs a transportation service business. He offers regular transportation services, as well as ceremonial services at funerals. He owns two vehicles: a car and a hearse. He started his business twelve years ago. Currently, he gets 5000 UAH in income each month.

Sergyi is seeking a loan of 7000 UAH to perform major repairs on his car engine. It is the main source of income for his family. Sergyi is hoping to generate additional income and to invest it in refurbishment of his apartment and improvement of his living conditions.

loans.use: To repair the engine of his vehicle

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet has been selling groceries and crates of eggs for six years. She loves her business, because her customers pay in cash. She does not sell on credit to her customers. She is hoping for a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and crates of eggs to sell.

In the future, Juliet hopes to own a world-class supermarket. She is 40 years old and married with seven children. Her youngest child is 4 years old. Her children attend school, and they are excelling.

Juliet is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. She thanks all Kiva lenders. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Natasha

texts.en:
Natasha is married and has a grown son. She lives in Mukachevo. Natasha runs a small retail store called "Scarlett" that is located in downtown Mukachevo. She sells items such as purses, umbrellas, and wallets in her little store. Natasha's enterprise is popular among customers, as it has a favorable location and merchandise is offered at affordable prices. Natasha opened her retail store eight years ago. Presently, she has 35,000 UAH worth of inventory. Her gross income amounts to 15,000 UAH per month.

Natasha is seeking a loan of 7500 UAH to increase her working capital. She works hard to balance her profit and expenses. Despite the financial challenges many small entrepreneurs in Ukraine face these days, Natasha keeps pressing on, hoping for a positive outcome. At HOPE Ukraine/Nadiya, we believe that Natasha's natural determination and hard work will help her succeed in her entrepreneurial endeavors.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena sells crates of eggs at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to be a major distributor of eggs in her community in Sapele. She hopes for a loan of N80,000 to purchase more crates of eggs to sell.

Philomena is 43 years old and married with four children who are excelling in their education. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Pelagie

texts.en:
Pelagie is 43 years old and is married with seven children aged between 2 and 20 years. She and her family live in the Gasabo district of Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Pelagie owns a small shop that sells various products such as cosmetics products, foodstuffs, and so forth. She has been entrepreneur since 2005 and her business is well-known which is very advantageous for her because it means she gets enough customers to her shop.

Pelagie employs one person in her business as a helper. The hours of her business are from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day, even during the weekend.

So far, Pelagie is not able to satisfy the demands of her clients through offering them a greater quantity of products. She is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to grow her business through purchasing more products to satisfy the demands of her clients.

The profits Pelagie expects to earn will be reinvested in her business so that her monthly profits increase. Once the profits are enough, she will be able to feed her children and save money for building a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is married with two daughters. She is an entrepreneur from Novaya Kahovka where she sells children’s clothing in one of the local malls called “Tsentralnyi”. Lubov was forced to launch her own enterprise 15 years ago when the whole country was struck by economic collapse. She managed to consistently grow and develop her startup and achieved its consistent expansion. Currently, Lubov has about 25,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her net profit amounts to 6,500 Grivnyas a month.  

Lubov is requesting a 15,000-Grivnya loan to increase her turnover capital. She always says she is ready to excel to please her customer. We believe the way Lubov makes her clients feel will determine her further success, encouraging new customers to buy from her.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Petro

texts.en:
Petro is married. He is a small businessman from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. Petro owns a chicken farm where he breeds poultry for sale. He has one big advantage compared to his competitors: Petro’s brother owns a small chicken meat processing shop. They partner in their work and as a result, their businesses benefit each other. Petro has been in this business for seven years. Presently, he has 15,000 Grivnyas in working capital.   

Petro is seeking a 5,000-Grivnya loan to purchase poultry stock and further grow his venture. Petro realizes the area where he lives is predominantly agricultural, which doesn’t leave him many other business options. Therefore, he tries to embrace the potential his enterprise has to offer to ensure decent living for his family.

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Tawopaneh Ii Group

texts.en:
Here are the members of the Tawopaneh II group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to add more goods in their businesses. In this way, they will be able to make more sales and better profit. Consequently, they can better support their children in terms of feeding, clothing and in their academic pursuit. 

Beatrice C. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. She is 45 years of age and was born in Makeni City. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools, respectively. Fatmata sells market food: margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, sugar, plastic bags, butter and so on. She has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will buy more of the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her current stock. 

(Attached on the photo is a group member who was not present for the group snapshot)

loans.use: Buy margi, salt, sugar, plastic bags, butter etc

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace, who loves and hopes to excel in her business, sells frozen foods at retail prices to her customers. She is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more frozen foods to sell. Grace is the married mother of four children, her youngest just three years old. Her children are excelling in school and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 32-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Hussein has owned a grocery store since 2007. He sells candies, chips, beverages, and lots more. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a refrigerator for soft drinks and merchandise for his work. This is his second loan, and, in the past, he has always paid on time. His previous loan allowed him to purchase merchandise and to diversify his merchandise. When he first started his business, he had to navigate financial issues, knowing that he couldn't purchase all the needed merchandise. He decided on doing his business because of his experience.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise and a refrigerator for soft drinks

loans.name: Cookery Women Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the Cookery Women Group. They are small-scale businesswomen who are based in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, to make more profit, and, consequently, to improve their standard of living.

Isatu S. I is the leader of this group. Isatu was born in Kambia in northern Sierra Leone. She is 50 years old and married to a farmer. They have three children. One child is attending secondary school, and the other two children are attending primary school. For more than 10 years now, Isatu has sold cooked rice, meat, and vegetables. With her share of this loan, she will buy cooking materials such as rice, palm oil, meat, onions, and tomatoes in large quantities.

(Please note: In the middle of the photo is a former group member who is no longer a group member.)

loans.use: To buy cooking materials such as rice, palm oil, meat, onions, and tomatoes in large quantities

loans.name: Tamemsu Traders Group

texts.en:
These are the members of the Tamemsu Traders Group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs in the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of 4,000,000 SLL (1,000,000 SLL each) to enable them to further strengthen their businesses. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in size and quality. Consequently, they will make more sales and a better profit. As their profit-to-sales margin increases, they will be able to better support themselves and their children.

The leader of this group is Samuel I. K.. Samuel was born in the city of Makeni. He is age 45. He is married and has three children. Samuel's children are attending secondary school. He sells both soft and hard drinks. He has been in this business for many years now. He will use this loan to buy more drinks to add to his current stock.

(Attached on the left of the photo is a group member who was not present for the group photo.)

loans.use: To buy crates of soft and hard drinks

loans.name: La Bendicion 3,4,5 Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group La Bendicion (The blessing), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, a poor agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their nine children.

Ana is excited to be taking her ninth loan with Esperanza after having fully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling used clothing by purchasing large packages of used clothing imported to the DR from organizations such as The Salvation Army in the United States. She will then sell the clothing in her community, using the profits to provide for the daily needs of her large family and to pay the transportation costs for her children to go to school. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Used Clothing to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali, a 32-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children, has owned a barber shop since 2000. When he first started his business, he had difficulty finding the proper place to open his shop. He decided to work as a hairdresser because he had gained experience in his previous work. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work.

This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him to purchase tools for his work as well as improve his barber shop. Ali is now requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase an electric motor and a washing chair for his salon.

loans.use: To purchase an electric motor and washing chair for his salon.

loans.name: Nasser

texts.en:
Nasser is a 19-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Nasser has owned a grocery store since 2009. He sells candies, roaster, beverages and lots more. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. 

This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. Nasser is special in his work because he is welcoming. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to diversify his merchandise. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Rabih

texts.en:
Rabih is a 35-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Rabih has been working in agriculture for over 15 years. He plants vegetables depending on the season. He also owns a truck which allows him to work. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, in order to pay for the harvesting of his work merchandise. This is the first time that Rabih has requested a loan. 

He is special in his work because he does his best to produce the best quality of olives and oil. His clients are people from his region, as well as people from different regions. He decided on doing his business because it was his family’s business. When he first started his business, he didn’t produce as much as he does today. In the future, he plans to keep on expanding his work by producing more.

loans.use: To pay for harvesting

loans.name: Chidima

texts.en:
Chidima is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organisation) client. LAPO, a Kiva partner, is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. 

Chidima has a stall where she sells used clothes and bags. Her customers are usually residents, friends and neighbors. She hopes to own a classic boutique in the future. 

She hopes for a loan of 90,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more used clothes and bags to sell. She is 27 years old and married with two children. Her eldest child is 4 years old, while her youngest child is 2 years old. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes and bags to sell

loans.name: Georges

texts.en: Georges, a 38-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife, has owned dairy-producing livestock for over ten years. This is the first loan he has requested from Al Majmoua; he wants to purchase sheep and goats to increase his livestock. Georges, who embarked on this enterprise when he took over his family’s business, faced no start-up difficulties. His clients can be anyone from his region. In the future, he plans to keep on producing dairy products and increase his livestock.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and goats to increase his livestock.

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en: Mouhamad is a 42-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Mouhamad has been working in agriculture for over 15 years. To facilitate his work, he uses a truck, which allows him to mow the field. He plants potatoes and other vegetables depending on the season. He is special in his work because he is known for his good production. His clients are people from his region. He decided on doing his business because he took over his family’s business. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua to do some maintenance work on his truck. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his truck.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort has a poultry farm where she sells poultry to make a living in Sapele. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She hopes for a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more poultry to sell. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract and retain more customers to her business. She is 64 years old and married with seven children. Her youngest child is 27 years old. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens.

loans.name: Charito Roxana

texts.es:
Charito es una madre de familia de 26 años de edad que vive junto  su esposo y sus dos hijos de ocho y seis años de edad en el sector Macabi del distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a 3 horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Hace seis meses instaló en su vivienda una bodega en la que ofrece a sus clientes productos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar, aceite), abarrotes, golosinas y bebidas. Ella nos comenta que inició su negocio en casa de su madre, que queda cerca al colegio del lugar, allí ella vendía golosinas y algunos útiles escolares a los estudiantes y poco a poco fue ahorrando e instalando su negocio.

Charito desea implementar su bodega con la compra de útiles escolares ya que se acerca el inicio de clases en los colegios del país. Por este motivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de mercadería para lograr su objetivo.

Charito es una madre trabajadora y responsable, es muy entregada a su familia y da todo de si para sacarlos adelante. Su mayor anhelo es bridarles a sus hijos una educación de calidad que les garantice un próspero porvenir.
texts.en:
Charito is 26 years old, married, and a mother of two young children, age 6 and 8. She and her family live in Macabi, Paijan, in the province of Ascope, which is part of the La Libertad region. She lives about three hours from the city of Chiclayo. About six months ago, Charito opened a canteen in her home. She sells staples like rice, sugar and oil, as well as snacks and drinks. She started her business in her mother's home, near a school. She sold candy and school supplies while saving up to move her shop. As the school season approaches, Charito wants to add school supplies to her canteen. This is why she has asked for a loan from Edpyme Alternativa. Charito is a hard-working, responsible woman who nothing more than to help her family. She hopes to give her children the kind of education that will ensure them a bright future.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying school supplies

loans.name: Haydar

texts.en: Haydar is a 24-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Haydar has owned a bakery for 10 years. He sells and produces mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza. The most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it any time of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Haydar is special in his work because he is known for his good and tasty mankoucheh. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw materials and a motorcycle because he plans to start doing delivery. This is the first time that he has requested a loan. He decided on doing his business because that’s what he always wanted to do, and he is known for his mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase raw material and a motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 49-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Mahmoud has been selling fruits and vegetables since 2003. He sells oranges, apples, tangerines, lemons, iceberg lettuce, cucumbers, tomatoes, radishes and more, depending on the season. Mahmoud decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his family’s business. His family has been working as farmers. Therefore, he decided to open his fruits and vegetables shop in order to sell the things his family produces. This is the first time he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. With his loan, he intends to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell from other farmers so that he can increase and diversify his sales. His clients are people from his region, but mainly his friends and neighbors. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and his income.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 33-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ali has been selling home products since 2005. He sells batteries, bulbs, and other things. He decided on doing this business because he took over his friend’s business. Therefore, the shop already had its own clients and was known in his region, which allowed him to not face lots of difficulties when he became the owner of the place. This is the first time he has requested a loan from A. Majmoua. With his loan, he plans to purchase merchandise for his shop to increase his sales, and repair the car he uses in his work to transport tools from the shop to different work places.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.

loans.name: Aticlan Group

texts.es: El grupo aticlan, se han unido  hace 5 años atras para poder salir avante y mantener a sus hijos y mantener a ellas misma,Ellas se han dedicado a la fabricacion de delantales para damas, y ellas salen a vender en distinta partes de Solola y Totonicapàn, pero viendo la necesidad de ampliar y obtener mas ganancias Acuden a la ASOCIACION ASDIR  para este apoyo. y para tener una mejor nivel de vida.
texts.en:
The group Aticlan was formed 5 years ago, so that its members could get ahead and support their children and themselves. They work making women's aprons, which they sell in different parts of Solola and Totonicapàn. Seeing the need to expand their business and increase their earnings, and in order to have a better standard of living, they came to the Asociacion ASDIR for support.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital for business making and selling aprons

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy wheat

loans.name: Amena

texts.en: Amena is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with her husband and their child. Amena has owned a housewares shop for two years. She sells dishes, trays, tea and coffee cups and more. She also sells some home decoration items like tablecloths, towels,napkins, etc. She requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop like cups, forks, spoons, dishes and different raw materials for her shop. When she first started her shop, she didn’t face any difficulties. Now thanks to her loan, she wants to enlarge her sales and diversify her merchandise to answer her clients' demands.  She decided on doing her business because she wanted to work and supplement her family’s income. In the future, she plans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: San Pedro Group

texts.es:
El grupo San Pedro está integrado por tres personas muy responsables, trabajadoras y esforzadas ellos son de Ticuantepe, Managua. Este Municipio es de raíces indígenas gran parte de este es rural y se encuentra entre Nindiri y Managua. 

La señora Virginia Azucena Velázquez C. empezó vendiendo pocas gaseosas en su casa luego por medio de los préstamos ha ido creciendo y actualmente distribuye mayor cantidad de dicho producto. Esta señora 45 años viendo la necesidad de acrecentar su negocio y suplir la demanda de su clientela  invertirá  en la compra de mayor cantidad de gaseosas.

Mientras sus compañeros de grupo se dedican otro tipo de comercios la señora Ivania del Socorro G. vende comida y Norlan Dervi C. P. tiene una pequeña distribuidora de pollo. Ellos invertirán el préstamo en sus respectivos negocios.
texts.en:
The group "San Pedro" is made up of 3 persons who are very hardworking, responsible and dedicated. They are from Ticuantepe, Managua. This town, lying between Nindiri and Managua, has indigenous roots and a large part is rural. Virginia Azucena Velázquez C. started out selling a few soft drinks from her home. Later, through some loans, she increased her business and currently she distributes a large quantity of this product. She is 45 years old. Seeing the need to grow her business and supply the demand of her customers, she will invest in the purchase of a larger quantity of soft drinks. Meanwhile, her fellow group members are involved in other commercial activities. Ivania del Socorro G. sells food and Norlan Dervi C. P. has a small chicken distribution business. They will invest the loan in their respective businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy soft drinks

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en: Alaa is a 21-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Alaa has been working as a car repairer since 2004. He also sells used car spare parts. He decided on doing his business because of his experience and because he likes to this job. He likes challenges and for him, repairing a car is always challenging. When he first started his business, he had some difficulties building networks and purchasing all the necessary tools for his work. Now, for the time, he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua because he wants to purchase new and more sophisticated tools, and to renew some stone rock decorations at his house because he plans to get married. In the future, he hopes and plans to keep improving his work and his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase new and more sophisticated tools.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 36-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Hassan has owned and operated a mobile phone store for almost two years. He sells new and used mobile phones and accessories like covers, chargers, earphones, and more. He decided on doing his business because of his experience in sales and mobile phones, since he used to work in a mobile shop before. When he first started, he had some financial issues because opening a mobile phone shop requires a lot of money to buy his merchandise. For the first time, he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and new mobile devices. Hassan’s clients are mainly people from his region. In the future, he plans to improve his work by starting to repair mobile phones.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and new mobile devices.

loans.name: El Buen Futuro 1 Group

texts.en:
Ramona is the coordinator of her group El Buen Futuro (The Good Future), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Hato Mayor, a poor, rural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with three children.

Ramona is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing and underwear by traveling to the capital, Santo Domingo, and purchasing bras, panties, women's pants and blouses to sell in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to invest in her home (by replacing her wooden walls with concrete block) and in her children (by purchasing notebooks and backpacks). She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 51 years old and married with nine children ranging in age from 31 down to 11 years old. Four of the children are currently attending school. She operates a mixed farm in western Kenya, just outside the city of Kitale. She's been farming for eight years and sells eggs and milk products at the local retail outlets near her home. She also earns income from her involvement in other horticulture activities and in making and selling charcoal. She says that the main challenges to her business are the high prices for chicken feed and her overall high expenses in maintaining the farm.

Jane requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 30,000 to purchase material that will enable her to build a bigger poultry house.  She also will be purchasing other farm inputs for the upcoming season. She said that this loan will help increase the family's income and diversify her production into more poultry and dairy farming. In the future, she would like to own at least five dairy animals at her farm.

Jane recently completed her first loan through Juhudi Kilimo before applying for this loan and she appreciates the changes in her life.  She hopes to maintain a relationship with the institution and build up her credit levels so she can purchase a dairy animal in the near future.

loans.use: Build a bigger poultry house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase palm trees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a posho mill

loans.name: Primera Esperanza Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group Primera Esperanza (First Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Hato Mayor, a poor, agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their child.

Maria is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling new clothing by purchasing jeans, polo shirts, and blouses in Santo Domingo in the main market and then selling them in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to invest in a new floor for her family, which will improve sanitary conditions. She will also save for the university education of her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy new clothing to sell

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
María A. de 25 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Suburbio de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento si cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, es soltera.

María empezó con un restaurante pequeño pero no le resulto y decidió poner una pequeña tienda en su casa vendiendo sus primeros productos como arroz, azúcar.

Ahora María trabaja desde las 06h30 hasta las 23h00 todos los días vende en su tienda bebidas, confitería, arroz, azúcar, artículos para papelería etc. Trabaja en conjunto con su mama, no ha tenido inconvenientes hasta ahora en su tienda. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, bebidas, vegetales para su tienda. En el futuro quiere tener su propio Minimarket y ya tener su propia familia.
texts.en:
María A., 25, lives in "El Suburbio," an urban neighborhood in Guayaquil. Her home is made of cement and has all of the basic services. She is single. Maria started out with a small restaurant, but this business did not work out, so she decided to put a small store in her house where she sells basic necessities such as rice and sugar. Now Maria works from 6:30 in the morning until 11 at night every day selling drinks, sweets, rice, sugar, paper products, etc. She works along with her mother, and so far she has not had any difficulties with her store. With the loan she wants to buy rice, drinks, and vegetables for her store. In the future, when she has her own family, she wants to have her own Minimarket.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rice, drinks and vegetables

loans.name: Dos Combo Group

texts.es:
El grupo Dos Combos está iniciando en Adim este es su primer crédito con el cual esperan mejorar su negocio. Este lo conforman Emilia del Carmen Z. Sánchez de quien vende ropa por encargo con lo cual apoya a sus cuatro hijos menores de edad, Maritza del Socorro L. tiene un taller de costura y Paula Emilia Sánchez Tiene una pequeña pulpería la cual inicio con la venta de de gaseosas, chiverías y dulces y poco a poco ha ido surtiendo.

Ellas invertirán el crédito en la compra de materia prima para sus respectivos negocios con lo cual esperan mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
The group Dos Combos is beginning in Adim. This is the group's first loan, which the members are hoping will improve their businesses. The group is made up of Emilia del Carmen Z. Sánchez, who sells clothes to order to support her four young children; Maritza del Socorro L., who has a dress-making business; and Paula Emilia Sánchez, who has a small grocery store that she began by selling soft drinks, yogurt, and candies and little by little grew. The women will use the loan to buy material goods for their respective businesses, with which they hope to improve their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothes to sell

loans.name: Sol Naciente Group

texts.es:
La señora María de Lourdes R., vive en la comunidad de Valle de Chalco Solidaridad, en el Estado de México; es casada  y tiene 4 hijos, la mayor tiene 14 años de ahí sigue el otro de 4 años, después otro de 2 años y el mas pequeño tiene apenas 2 meses de nacido; ella se dedica a la venta de frutas y legumbres en casa por casa, anteriormente era el esposo que se dedicaba al comercio debido a que los gastos en la familia se han incrementado la señora María de Lourdes desde hace 2 años se dedica al comercio, su necesidad es la compra de un puesto armable para vender sus productos, ya que actualmente lo hace con un triciclo en donde embolsa por kilo las frutas y verduras y es como realiza su venta, con las ganancias que genere ella lo quiere ahorrar porque en donde vive es de familiares, y sus hijos están creciendo y no cuenta con una vivienda que sea propio; por esa razón apoya a su esposo con los gastos para que juntos puedan lograr ahorrar y dejarle a sus hijos un patrimonio.
A ella la invita una amiga que se llama Chuy a que se integre al grupo de Sol naciente en donde pueden ahorrar y a la vez recibir crédito a través de Fundación Realidad y pueda cumplir sus expectativas de vida como cada una de las integrantes del grupo y solicitar dicho crédito.
Las personas que integran el grupo son:
Ma Cristina G. Hernández  vende abarrotes.
Catalina Jiménez M. vende antojitos.
María de Lourdes R. Jiménez vende frutas  y verduras(en la foto esta cargando un bebe).
Jesus González A. vende productos por catalogo.
Rita Hernández Guzmán vende productos por catalogo.
Erika Ramírez vende artículos de bonetería y mercería.
Dulce María R. Jiménez vende lencería por catalogó.
Martha B. Ramírez Hernández vende dulces.
Marco Antonio B. González Tiene un puesto de música.
María De Los Ángeles Limón C. vende dulces.
texts.en:
Señora María de Lourdes R. lives in the community of Valle de Chalco Solidaridad, in the state of México. She is married and has four children, the oldest is 14 years old and from there her other is 4, the next is 2, and the youngest is just 2 months old. She works selling fruits and vegetables house by house. Before it was her husband who worked commercially in order to meet the expenses of the family, which had increased. Señora María de Lourdes has for two years worked selling door to door. She needs to buy a transportable way to carry the products she sells. She has made due with a tricycle where she loads kilos of fruits and vegetables to make her sales. With the income she generates, she wants to save because she lives with her relatives, and her children are growing and she wants to give them a place to live that is their own. Because of this, she is helping her husband with the expenses so that together they can save and leave their children an inheritance. She is inviting her friend Chuy, who is part of the group Sol Naciente, where she can save and at the same time receive a loan from Fundación Realidad so she can complete her goals for life, like one of the members of the group, asking for the said credit. The people who make up the group are: Ma Cristina G. Hernández who sells groceries. Catalina Jiménez M. who sells typical Mexican snacks. María de Lourdes R. Jiménez who sells fruits and vegetables (in the photo, she is carrying a baby). Jesus González A. who sells products by catalog. Rita Hernández Guzmán who sells products by catalog. Erika Ramírez who sells clothing articles and merchandise. Dulce María R. Jiménez who sells lingerie by catalog. Martha B. Ramírez Hernández who sells sweets. Marco Antonio B. González who has a music stand. María De Los Ángeles Limón C. who sells sweets.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: In order to buy fruits and vegetables, Mexican snacks, clothing, and women's items.

location.town: Valle De Chalco Solidaridad  Estado De Mexico

loans.name: Olga Janneth

texts.es:
Olga Janneth D.  es socia activa del banco comunal Mujer y Fortaleza  hace seis ciclos gracias a su  cuñada que la incentivó a formar parte de este gran grupo de mujeres formado en la parroquia Turi al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, sector conocido como el balcón de la ciudad es muy turístico por la belleza natural del campo, la gastronomía y la amabilidad de su gente, la mayor parte de su población  se dedica a la agricultura y también a otras  actividades que les permiten establecerse económicamente para así poder salir adelante.

Olga es una  mujer de 25 años está felizmente casada su esposo es guardia de seguridad de un local  comercial y tiene dos hijos de 8 y 9 años, es  muy  alegre y siempre ve lo positivo de cada día y así triunfar en la vida, es costurera de profesión pues estudio  por tres  años en una academia, al momento se dedica a la confección y venta de blusas lleva dos años en esta actividad en su taller ubicado en su  casa, nos comenta que  los créditos le han beneficiado para comenzar con su propio negocio.

Además manifiesta que no tiene casa propia y vive en casa de sus padres compartiendo con ellos los gastos, y  con el dinero que reciba del préstamo solicitado va a comprar telas, hilos, cierres, botones y más materiales para la confección de sus blusas para incrementar su taller de costura que es su gran sueño.
texts.en:
Olga Janneth D. has been an active member of the community bank Mujer y Fortaleza ("Woman and Strength") for six loan cycles thanks to her mother-in-law, who motivated her to become part of this great group of women. Mujer y Fortaleza is based in the parish of Turi, which is southeast of the city of Cuenca. Turi is known as the city's balcony. It is a very touristic area because of the countryside's natural beauty, the gastronomy, and the good-hearted nature of its people. The majority of Turi's population works in agriculture. People also work in other activities that allow them to establish themselves economically in order to move forward in life. Olga is a 25 year-old woman happily married to her husband, who is a security guard in a local store. She has two children who are 8 and 9 years sold. She is very happy and always looks at the positive of every day, and because of this triumphs in live. She works as a seamstress and studied for three years in an academy to do this. Currently she works making and selling blouses. She has spent two years doing this from the workshop located in her house. She tells us that the loans have helped her begin her own business. Furthermore, she expresses that she does not have her own house, so she lives in her parents' house and shares household costs with them. With the money she receives from the requested loan she will buy fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, and other materials needed to make blouses in order to build her business, which is his her big dream.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, and other materials needed to make blouses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of alcoholic beverages.

loans.name: Pablo Absalon

texts.es: El señor Pablo es un hombre trabajador, padre de familia de tres hijos mayores, tiene 63 años de edad, casado, su compañera es costurera y juntos se ayudan, para poder cubrir los gastos. Su negocio es una pulpería que tiene en su casa de habitación en el barrio Villa Reconciliación. El inicio este negocio con venta de atoles, arroz en leche, cereales, golosinas, el cual comenzó ambulante en un carretón en donde día a día, vende por las calles, su variada de productos, el cual gracias a estos financiamientos logro comprar esta carreta y esta contento por que ha logrado crecer en su negocio. Con este préstamo comprara granos básicos, carnes, pollos  golosinas, ase, jabón, lácteos. Para mejorar las ventas. Su esposa le ayuda cuando el anda en su carreta vendiendo ambulante ya que tienes sus clientes que le compran y mueve más su dinero. Es cansado pero tiene que vender para cubrir sus necesidades de alimentos como pagos básicos de agua, luz, y el abono del préstamo.
texts.en:
Mr. Pablo is a hard-working man. He is 63 years old married father of three grown children. His wife is a seamstress, and they work to help each other and cover household costs. He has a small grocery store, which he runs from his home in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood. He began his business selling a warm corn drink, rice with milk, cereal, and sweets from a traveling cart. Every day, he would sell his variety of products on the streets. Thanks to the loans he received he was able to buy his own cart, and he is happy because it has allowed him to grow his business. With this loan Mr. Pablo will buy basic grains, meats, chicken, soft drinks, roast, soap, and dairy products to increase his sales. His wife helps him when he walks with his cart selling in the streets since he already has his customers and money moves more quickly. It is tiring work, but he has to sell to cover his family's basic needs like paying for water, light, and loan payments.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying basic grains, meats, chicken, soft drinks, roast, soap, and dairy products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of palm nuts to make red oil.

loans.name: Catalino

texts.en: Catalino is 28 years old and financially independent.  He studied in a technical school where he learned to repair cell phones.  Since 2006, he has run his own shop in which he repairs and sells cell phones and cell phone credit.  Catalino began his business with help from his parents, and later was able to expand his operations through the business' earnings.  He is very well located, only a few meters from the bus station.  Catalino is seeking the loan to purchase cell phones and accessories, which will afford his business a greater variety of products to sell.  This should increase Catalino's earnings.

loans.use: To purchase cell phones and accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine.

loans.name: María Margarita

texts.es:
El banco Comunal Mujer y Fortaleza se formó en la parroquia Turi al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, sector conocido como el balcón de la ciudad es muy turístico por la belleza natural del campo, la gastronomía y la amabilidad de su gente, la mayor parte de su población  se dedica a la agricultura y a otras  actividades que les permiten salir adelante junto a sus familias.

La señora María G.  es socia de éste banco hace tres ciclos, goza de  una gran amistad con todas las integrantes de su banco  y es una mujer muy alegre, tiene 28 años de edad es casada y tiene cinco  hijos que se encuentran de 9, 7, 4, 2 años y el ultimo de 2 meses, su esposo es albañil y la casa en la que habitan es propia siendo el fruto de muchos años de trabajo.

Nuestra socia vive a las afueras de la ciudad de Cuenca  en el sector Punta Corral, se dedica al cultivo de tierras ajenas los días que le dan  trabajo y los otros  a cultivar sus propias tierras y al cuidado de sus animales pues   posee dos borregos y una ternera que los adquirió con los créditos obtenidos de la Fundación, y con el  dinero que reciba del nuevo préstamo va a comprar pollos y alimento  para montar este nuevo negocio. Su meta es dar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
The "Mujer y Fortaleza" [Woman and Strength] Communal Bank was formed in the parish of Turi, southeast of the city of Cuenca. It is an area known as the "balcony of the city" and is popular with tourists due to the natural beauty of the land, the excellent food, and the friendliness of its people. Most of the population works in agriculture and in other activities that allow them and their families to get ahead. María G. has been a member of the bank for three loan cycles, and is friendly with all the other members. She is a happy woman, 28 years old and married with five children. The older ones are 9, 7, 4 and 2 years old, and the littlest one is 2 months old. Her husband is a bricklayer and their many years of hard work have enabled them to own their own home. María G. lives on the outskirts of Cuenca in the Punta Corral area. She works tending others' fields on the days in which she can find such work, and on the other days she tends to her own land and animals. She has two lambs and a calf that she bought with funds borrowed through the Kiva field partner, and with the money from this new loan she is going to buy chickens and feed to get this new endeavor going. Her goal is to give her children a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chickens and corn for their feed

loans.name: José Abrahán

texts.es:
El Sr. José Abrahán C. V. es empleado, trabaja como conserje en el centro de salud del Municipio de Condega.

Este cliente solicita dicho crédito para el pago de unos exámenes medico y la compra de medicamento para su esposa ya que ella esta un mal de salud, esto exámenes tiene que realízalos en la capital y son muy costosos igual que el medicamento.

El Sr. Abrahán C. a trabajado en este centro de salud desde hace 5 años, antes de trabajar aquí el estaba trabajando en un centro escolar de estudios secundarios realizando el mismo trabajo. El realiza sus labores de trabajado de lunes a sábado desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde.

Este cliente espera que con la compra de estos medicamentos y exámenes su esposa se recupere del mal estado de salud en que se encuentra y así tener mejor tranquilidad y felicidad en su hogar. Cabe señalar que este cliente es casado pero no tiene hijos.

Este es el crédito numero seis que el Sr. Abrahan Centebno tiene en Ceprodel en un periodo de 3 años, estos financiamiento han tenido un impacto positivo en la vida de Don Abrahán ya que con ellos a logrado realizar mejoras en su casa de habitación como la instalación de la energía eléctrica mejorando así de esta manera su condiciones de vida de el y su esposa y con el futuro hacer mas.
texts.en:
Mr. José Abrahán C. V. is employed, working as a receptionist in the health center in the municipality of Condega. He is asking for this loan so that he can pay for some medical exams and buy medicine for his wife who is in poor health. These exams, which must take place in the capital, are very expensive, as is the medicine. Mr. Abrahán C. has worked in the health center for five years. Before he worked here, he was working in a center for secondary studies, where he did the same work. He works Monday through Saturday from 7 in the morning until 4 in the afternoon. He hopes that with the purchase of these medicines and exams his wife will recover from her current state poor health and will be more peaceful and happy in their home. It should be said that Mr. Abrahán C. is married but does not have children. This is the sixth loan Mr. Abrahan Centebno has had with Ceprodel in a 3 year period. These loans have had a positive impact on his life, because with them he has been able to make improvements on his house like installing electricity, which improves the quality of life for him and his wife. He hopes in the future he will be able to do more.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of medical exams and purchase of medicine

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
El comité “Santa Librada” se formó con la unión varias vecinas del barrio Santa Librada, de la ciudad de Villa Elisa.
 Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas. Las integrantes formaron un grupo  muy unido y capaz de realizar actividades en forma conjunta, ya que la mayoría de sus integrantes se dedican a la venta, siendo así la mayoría de ellas, colegas entre si..
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a dichas actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable. 
Así como la señora Florencia B. quien se dedica a la venta de ropa, esta actividad lo realiza de forma ambulante ya que las ventas no son tan buenas en el salón de su casa, ella visita a cada cliente para ofrecer sus productos. 
Se citan las actividades de cada una de las integrantes.
1
Marilina G.
Venta  de Quiniela

texts.en:
The group “Santa Librada” was formed by a group of neighbors from the Santa Librada neighborhood in the city of Villa Elisa. All the women in the group have their own independent businesses, such as sales. The members have formed a very united group capable of realizing activities together. The majority of the members work in sales as colleagues. All the members of the committee are mothers who work in their respective fields with the goal of strengthening their household budgets and building their businesses in a sustainable manner. Mrs. Florencia B. sells clothes for a living. She does so by traveling around the city. Because sales have not been that well from her home, she visits each customer to offer her products. Here are the activities of each of the members: 1. Marilina G., sports pool/lottery sales 2. Florencia B., clothes sales 3. Visitacion M., clothes sales 4. Ana Rosa C., baking 5. Ramona R., cosmetics sales 6. Nolberta V., sports pool/lottery sales 7. Yenny R., sports pool/lottery sales 8. Limpia C., beverage sales 9. Reina L., snack sales 10. Aurora R., coupon sales 11. Nilza R., baking 12. Hilaria C., clothes sales 13. Sonia L., food sales 14. Maria P., coupon sales 15. Nilda V., fruit sales

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying shirts, blouses, pants, and dresses

loans.name: Tuwisana Plus Group

texts.en:
Papy K., aged 31 and unmarried, is the president of the Community Bank named “Tuwisana Plus”, which is composed of 32 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through the MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses. 

Papy started his business in 2007 with $30 in initial capital. He manages his own general store located west of the city of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of the MFI HOPE DRC who has already received four different loans and has repaid them properly. He intends to use the next loan to buy goods to resell with the aim of increasing his profits. Each week, his business brings in a profit of $45. His ambition is to become a wholesaler in his area.

loans.use: To purchase goods to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of corn

loans.name: Los Tres Barrios - Qoricancha Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal  “ LOS TRES BARRIOS - QORICANCHA”, ellos están ubicados en la provincia de Urubamba en el distrito de Chinchero perteneciente al departamento del Cusco.

Nuestros socios se dedican al comercio minorista, entre los miembros del banco comunal en su gran mayoría se dedican a la ganadería y a la agricultura, como principal actividad; otras dos socias venden chicha, crían animales menores, otro socio es albañil y dos socios se dedican a la artesanía, y un socio fabrica baños sanitarios. Nuestra socia la Sra. Alejandrina Huamán L.; natural de chinchero, de la comunidad de Qoricancha, es casada y tiene 2 hijos estudió primaria completa y se dedicó de lleno a la crianza de ganados desde casi una niña, nuestra socia ahora se dedica a la compra y venta de ganados, ella viaja a la feria en la provincia de Quispicanchis a comprar ganados pequeños (maltones), los cría y engorda, saca nuevos ejemplares y a los papas después de un tiempo los venden, o también si tiene toros ella alquila para que se procreen con vacas de los vecinos, es toda una actividad algo compleja y dedicada, la socia solicita el préstamo para comprar algunos bebes de ganados.

Nuestros socios en general agradecen la oportunidad brindada y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Our members belong to the "Los Tres Barrios - Qoricancha" Communal Bank, located in the province of Urubamba, District of Chinchero, in the Department of Cusco. The majority of the bank members work in agriculture and raising cattle, with some working in retail sales as well. Two members work selling chicha [a fermented corn drink], another is a bricklayer, two work as craftsmen and one works making toilets. One member, Alejandrina Huamán L., who is originally from Chinchero and the Qoricancha community, is married and has two children. She completed a primary school education and has been raising cattle since she was practically a little girl. Now she works buying and selling cattle. She goes to the fair in Quispicanchis province to buy young animals. She then raises and fattens them, breeds and raises their young, and sells the older animals. When she has bulls she also rents them so that they can breed with her neighbors' cows. It is a complex and time-consuming job, and she is asking for this loan in order to buy new calves. All of our members are thankful for the opportunity offered by the loan process and promise to repay their loans within the established time period.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The member is requesting a loan to buy and sell cattle.

loans.name: Arlena Iveth

texts.es:
LA SRA. ARLENA ESTA CASADA Y VIVE EN LA CASA DE SU SUEGRA, CON QUIEN LLEVA UNA BUENA RELACION, TIENE DOS HIJOS PEQUEÑOS, SU ESPOSO TRABAJA CON TAXI PROPIO. COMO ACTIVIDAD ECONOMICA TIENE UNA TIENDA DE BARRIO INSTALADA EN SU DOMICILIO DONDE NO PAGA ALQUILER Y ATIENDE TODOS LOS DIAS LO CUAL LE DA TIEMPO PARA ATENDER DE SU FAMILIA. LA SRA ARLENA ES HUMILDE, JOVEN Y TRABAJADORA UNO DE SUS SUEÑOS ES PODER ESTUDIAR EN LA UNIVERSIDAD Y TENER UNA CARRERA PROFESIONAL PARA PODER ASI MEJORAR LA CALIDAD DE VIDA DE TODA SU FAMILIA.

EL DINERO DEL CREDITO LO INVERTIRA EN LA COMPRA DE MERCADERIA PARA SU TIENDA COMO SER: ABARROTES, REFRESCOS, DULCES, ETC.

LA SRA. ARLENA ESTA AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL  CREDITO.
texts.en:
Arlena is married and lives in her mother-in-law's house; she has a good relationship with her. She has two small children and her husband provides taxi services in his own vehicle. She has a small grocery store set up in her home where she can operate rent-free, be open every day and be able to tend to her family. Arlena is a young, unassuming, hard-working woman. One of her dreams is to be able to go to university and have a professional career so that she can improve her entire family's quality of life. The funding will be used to buy stock items for her store like: groceries, beverages, candy, etc. Arlena is grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in her upon granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her grocery store.

loans.name: Bettys Adalgisa

texts.es:
Bettys T. de 65 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Suburbio de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, su esposo le ayuda en la tienda con el tiene 6 hijo todos ya mayores de edad. 

Bettys empezó su negocio hace 30 años atrás, vendiendo arroz y azúcar poco a poco tuvo ingresos necesarios para vender más productos y tener algunas modificaciones en su negocio. 

Ahora Bettys trabaja todos los días desde las 06h30 hasta las 00h00, vendiendo arroz, enlatados, lácteos, verduras, etc. Algunas de las complicaciones que tiene son los cortes de energía que hace el gobierno. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, azúcar, lácteos para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener su negocio mas ampliado y así poder asegurar el futuro de su familia.
texts.en:
Bettys T. is 65 years old and lives in an urban area in the Guayaquil suburb. Her home is made of concrete and she has all the basic services, her husband helps her in the store, and she has 6 children with him, all are grown up.

Bettys began her business some 30 years ago selling rice and sugar and little by little she began getting profits that allowed her to sell more products and to make some improvements in her business.

Now Bettys works everyday from 06h30 to 00h00, selling rice, canned goods, milk products, vegetables, etc. Some of the problems that she has are the blackouts that the government does.

With the loan she will buy rice, sugar, milk products for her business. In the future she wants to expand her business and in this way secure the future of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and milk products.

loans.name: Jose Acencio

texts.es:
Jose tiene 55 años de edad, es casado, tiene nueve hijos, ya independizados, y vive junto a su esposa en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace mas de diez años tiene instalada en su vivienda una bodega en la que ofrece a sus clientes productos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar, aceite), abarrotes y golosinas. Este negocio se ha constituído como la unica fuente de ingresos con la que mantiene a su hogar.

El negocio goza de mucha acogida ya que la zona en donde vive está ubicada lejos del centro de la ciudad y sus vecinos siempre acuden a ella para obtener productos que consumen a diario.

Jose desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más productos de primera necesidad, por lo que se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el logro de su objetivo.

José es un padre responsable y bastante entregado a su familia y a su negocio. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Jose is 55 years old, is married and has 9 children, all grown up. He lives with his wife in the district of Paiján, province of Ascope, in the region of La Libertad, located 3 hours from the city of Chiclayo.

For more than 10 years, he has in his home a small grocery store where he offers his customers basic household goods (rice, sugar, oil), groceries and candy. This business is the only source of income for the household.

The business enjoys great acceptance in the area since where he lives is located far from the center of the city and his neighbors always use his store to get products that they consume daily.

Jose wishes to expand his business to buy more basic household goods, this is why he needs the loan from Edpyme Alternativa (Kiva’s field partner) for 1200 new soles and will spend the money to buy said goods.

Jose is a responsible father and is very devoted to his family and his business. He has already worked with our institution (Kiva’s field partner) before and has demonstrated to be responsible and punctual when making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic household goods to expand his business.

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
El comité “Maria Auxiliadora” se formó con la unión varias vecinas del barrio Bernardino Caballero, de la ciudad de Ypane. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas. 
Las integrantes formaron un grupo  muy unido y capaz de realizar actividades en forma conjunta, ya que la mayoría de sus integrantes se dedican a la venta, siendo así la mayoría de ellas, colegas entre si.
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a dichas actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable.
Las actividad que realiza la señora Petrona E. le resulta bastante bien en cuanto ya que los ingresos que obtiene con esta actividad le ayuda para la alimentación, y vestimenta de su familia.
Se citan la actividad de cada integrante:  
1
Petrona E.
Venta de Ropas
2
Patricia F.
Venta de Ropas
